1.content:
The date is 2144. Location: the Mizar sector in the Gytor system. You are Captain Jack Gunn, the youngest field Captain in the 110th expeditionary division of the 9th star fleet serving under Admiral Zane.

The 9th fleet has been fighting the Miras-Guhl non-stop for the past three weeks, and your defences are starting to give in. Commanders from the Helios and Regade sectors have reported that their lines have been breached. Within the next few hours the 9th fleet will fall – the outcome is inevitable.

“Captain Gunn, report to the bridge immediately, Captain Gunn”, you hear the female voice over the intercom system. Jumping up from the semi-circle of control consoles and electronic displays, you turn your command and control station over to your second in command.

“Keep an eye on quadrants E9 and E10, Ace. They love slipping in through there – I dispatched two drones to those sectors a few minutes ago and your readings should be clear.”

Running through the corridors of the star destroyer “America”, you cannot help but wonder why the commanders in the bridge would want to see you now. What could be more important than the recognisance and field intelligence work you have been doing for the past 72 hours. Rubbing your red eyes, you are suddenly reminded of how long it has been since you slept.

The scanner beeps as the door to the bridge opens, having read the identification chip in your chest. “Captain Gunn,” the electronic voice announces as you step onto the bridge.

A semi-circle of large portholes line the front and sides of the bridge. Approximately forty personnel members are frantically busy with their consoles. Turning around in his command chair in the centre of the room, the penetrating green eyes of Admiral Zane looks straight at you.

In his early sixties, his age is betrayed by his grey temples and the crows-feet on the sides of his eyes. A respected commander who is decorated with the highest honours of the Old-Earth Alliance, Zane has your respect, and that of the five thousand men serving on the “America”.

Standing up, Zane indicates you to follow him and leads you to his private office on the portside of the bridge. With the door closing behind you he gets straight to the point.

“Captain Gunn, what I am about to tell you could be the salvation for the Old-Earth Alliance. Never before have we come so close to victory, and never before have we come so close to defeat.”

Lighting a cigar, Zane continues.

“As you know the 9th fleet is on the verge of destruction. However, our mission has not been in vain. Two days ago a stealth-drone has reported on an extraordinary reading from the Xelesor system. We believe that the signal was emitted from a material on a planet in this system.”

Blowing a plume of smoke in the air, he continues. “Tracking this signal and recovering the material that emits it, has been our goal from the onset of this mission – being discovered and attacked by the Miras-Guhl has not.
“Captain Gunn, our scientists tell us that this material has the potential to nullify the need for the mineral Pylene since it can generate limitless amounts of energy. It can thereby end the decade long war with the Miras-Guhl, the war that has raged for what we thought was the last remaining energy source.”

Zane sits down, giving you time to digest the information he had just shared. “Furthermore, an energy source of this nature, will give us the power to dominate over the Miras-Guhl and end their realm of slavery, greed and their blood lust.”

“Now I suppose you wonder what your role is in all of this,” Zane says easily whilst putting out his cigar.

“We have four vessels on this ship that can potentially make this journey to the source of the signal. Under the circumstances we will launch all four within the hour with the sole mission to recover the material, and to return it to New-Earth. I say within the hour, because we might not be around much longer after that.”

“Captain, I tell you this because you will be tasked with commanding one of these vessels - your callsign will be Pathfinder seven-zero. Three other commanders are en route to receive the same orders. However, since you are here now, you get to choose which of the three vessels you would like to take on this mission.”

For a brief moment Zane pauses. Taking the gap, you blurt out, “Why me, sir?”
“Because you are one of few commanders with the necessary training and experience to complete this mission,” Zane responds. “And besides, most of the best commanders of the 9th fleet have been killed in the past week.”

Never one to mince words, Zane’s response leaves you feeling slightly insulted.

“So here are your choices Captain,” Zane continues flicking a switch on his personal computer.

“Choice one: The HR-122 Black Panther stealth ship. This baby is rigged with the latest and greatest technology. It is almost invisible and your flight should be quick and easy. Three problems though – firstly, you won’t be able to make it all the way there and back to New-Earth without stopping for Pylene. Secondly, you won’t be able to carry a full assault crew. You will get an Orion Commando, a science and medical officer and yourself. And finally, if you need to mine this mineral from the planet’s surface, you will have to improvise because the ship carries limited surface exploration equipment. This bird can get you there and back in one piece, but getting fuel, tracking the mineral and mining the mineral might be difficult.

Your pilot will be Lieutenant Phil “Buck” Rodgers. He finished top of his class in the Space Force Academy. As you know, the Orion Commando is elite Special Forces, and he will add valuable abilities to your unit. His name is Commander Spengler. He is typical Special Forces – quiet and reserved. His record is blank. All classified...you decide.”

“Choice two: The F-204 Scythe long range interceptor. Also a good choice. This bird is rigged to fight, but has limited stealth and cloaking abilities. With it, you will however get a full assault crew including six space marines, two Tiger-Cat mechanised units and two heavy-assault Rhino’s. Together with this you will have a science officer, a medical officer, an engineer and off course yourself. This choice will possibly involve contact with the enemy and you might have to search around before tracking the mineral. Also once you find it, mining might be somewhat difficult.

You will be able to pilot this ship yourself, but your co-pilot will be an ex-marine named Sergeant Sam Rico. A tough old bastard with hard earned experience. Turned to piloting when he received a mechanized leg after losing his in a fire fight. Good crew – solid choice. But be sure your balls are strapped on tight if you take this option.”

“Choice three: The CLK-800 Juggernaut prospector. Not actually a military vehicle. The advantage is that the Miras-Guhl might take it as one of their own and ignore you all together. It has no stealth or cloaking abilities, but it has a fully staffed laboratory with mineral detection add-ons and off course a full spectrum of mining equipment and operators. If you use the Juggernaut, you will find the mineral and mine it quickly and easily. You will also have three construction units. Also, you will be working under a disguise. However, being discovered is not an option since you won’t even be able to destroy a light scout...well maybe a scout.

You will need a pilot for this one. He is an ex-convict named Betty. You will have to decide for yourself if you can trust him. He might however prove resourceful in avoiding the Miras-Guhl since he has been avoiding the authorities for most of his life.”

“Choice four: The Freelancer 2200. It has numerous empty bays and pylons, a large cargo hold and a two Cyclone Interstellar engines, giving it long range abilities. Again, you will be posing as non-military. Its cargo hold is filled with 100 metric tons of Pylene, which you can either trade or use. As your crew you will have a master tradesman, a language expert, an engineer and an expert navigator. You will be able to pilot the ship yourself.

The master tradesman is known as Lord Freemen and he is very good at what he does. He is said to be slightly...well, let’s say mischievous.”

11.content:
Sliding in the behind the co-pilot’s controls, you look back over your shoulder to look at your crew. First in line you see Commander Spengler – the Orion Commando. His face is stern and serious. He is of average dimensions, with blonde hair and intense green eyes with steely determination.

Next in line, the science officer is busy buckling himself up. Officer Malcolm Spencer – having the IQ of a genius, you can imagine Spencer had already calculated that his chances of surviving this mission was slim to none. His thick, black framed glasses seemed to be a relic of the previous millennium.
You are surprised to see that your fifth and last crew member, the medical officer, is female. You estimate her to be in her early thirties, and she has an air of confidence about her. She is quite beautiful, but it seems that she has an edge about her – probably because of too many over-eager soldiers hitting on her.

“Strap yourselves in,” pilot Rodgers announces over his microphone. Retuning your eyes to the front, you see the large hangar doors sliding open.

“Pathfinder seven-zero; launch in five seconds,” the mechanical voice of the air-traffic control robot announces. “Four, three, two, one...”

The engine of your ship wines louder and then roares before launching you through the open hatch. The force of the acceleration forces you back into your chair as you speed into empty space. In a distance you see the flashes of a intense fire-fight.

“Activating stealth mode,” Rodgers says. The lights in the cockpit blinks off, followed by a red glow. “Stealth mode activated,” the onboard computer announces.
Your invisible stealth-ship slips through empty space.

“Our heading is set Captain,” Rodgers says over your ear-piece. “It takes us past three possible refuelling points. The first is Hector-Prime...a dirty little planet with not much more than some low-end vagabonds, gamblers and drug-dealers. The odds of finding Pylene on that shit-bucket is low, but not impossible. We shouldn’t find much resistance there however.

The second is Echo-Centauri. Here we have a high concentration of Miras-Guhl, but also numerous Pylene refineries. With our stealth abilities we should get in easy enough, but securing the Pylene could be cumbersome.

Last option is Procol-Kilia. It was originally built as a deep space refeuling facility but has since developed into a subsurface city. It usually crawls with both OEA and Guhl spies and therefore we need to be exrtra careful. Because it is subsurface we will have to time our landing taking its day cycle into account. The surface temperature reaches in access of 1000 degrees Celsius in day time, so we might have to hang around in orbit for a couple of hours before we can land. Since it was a refuelling station, Pylene will be easy to get. However to get there we will have to pass through an anomaly known as a Houston-Knox high energy field. Maybe Officer Spencer could tell us more about that.”

“Uh...yes...aaah”, officer Spencer starts taken aback by the sudden attention.

“The Houston-Knox field is not fully understood yet. It is basically like a cloud of energy with various types and strengths of energy. Experimentations on the fields have provided a huge mass of data, but in many cases the data is contradictory. There is even evidence that the field might influence the time-space continuum. So in short, we have no idea what that field might do to us...”
11.title: HR-122 Black Panther stealth ship

111.content:
We want to keep a low profile , so let’s head for Hector-Prime,” you say. “Besides, these types of places usually have the low-down on the most important things happening...maybe we could get some valuable Intel.”

Following your orders, Rodgers quickly punches in the coordinates and fires up the engines. “Hold on everyone...here we go...” with that the ship smoothly transitions to warp speed.

“Approaching Hector-Prime,” Rodgers says. “Initiating warp drive shut down,” he continues, focussing on the controls in front of him.

Seconds later, the galaxy containing Hector-Prime flashes into view. The ship zooms in on a green planet, the gravity regulator of the ship making the approach and stop effortless.

“Computer,” you say, “planet statistics please.”

“Planet: Hector-Prime,” the computer complies.
“Atmosphere composition: 78.91% nitrogen, 21.85% oxygen, 0.83% argon, 0.38% carbon dioxide, remainder – trace elements. Atmosphere, breathable.
Temperature: 25 to 35 degrees Celsius.
Climate: high rainfall, humidity 80%
Geology: Sand consisting of Silica, Quartz and limestone with high levels of organic deposits
Vegetation: Tropical – Triple canopy jungle
Life: Various life forms detected
Structures: Five clusters of structures detected ranging from very small to small.”

“Rodgers, take us to the largest cluster of structures”, you instruct. “We’ll circle and check out the environment before we disengage the ship’s cloak.”

Rodgers gently steers the ship forward and prepares to enter the atmosphere. Slipping into a planet’s atmosphere with a cloaked ship is usually pointless, since entry literally causes the ship to catch fire and leaves a nice trail of smoke across the horizon. However, many times it is misinterpreted as a comet or debris from space. In addition to this, the moment the heat of entry wears off, the ship is invisible again.

Tearing into the atmosphere, the cockpit window turns red from flames licking up from outside. The ship shakes and rumbles…and then it is over.

Below, the green landscape rolls by. Thick jungle covers the planet’s surface.

“Any info on this community we’re approaching”, you ask Rodgers.

“It’s called Scorpio”, Rodgers starts. “Population approximately one-thousand permanent residents. Mostly small time merchants and traders. A couple of bars…a small star port. Not much more to say. Apparently it is frequented by drug dealers since there is a type of plant they cultivate here that can be processed to produce a drug commonly known as Silk. With the war raging on, nobody has the resources for law enforcement in a distant planet such as this.”

“Our chances to get Pylene”, you ask.

“Not that good”, Rodgers answers. “Obviously the drug dealers and locals have to refuel somewhere, but it’s usually through local contacts or they fuel up before coming here…so we’ll have to see if we can get lucky.”

“How many units of Pylene do we need”, you ask.

“Our maximum capacity is thirty tons…I’d say we take as much as we can, because we don’t know when we can fill up again”, Rodgers replies.

With that, Rodgers pulls the ship in a tight left turn. “Lady and gentlemen, I give to you Scorpio”, he says.

Looking left you see a mushroom-like structure tower out above the jungle. The mushroom, you recognise, is a man-made platform approximately a thousand yards in circumference with a variety of structures clustered on it.

To one side, you recognise a moderate star port. Rodgers continues the tight turn, making the platform circle below you.

“Scan for any signals of communication”, you say, still scanning the structures.

“Only picking up local entertainment stations and low-end encrypted signals…probably the druggies placing another order…definitely no Guhl”, Rodgers responds quickly.

“All right”, you say. “Take us out so that we can de-cloak without being spotted, and then bring us back for a landing.”

Five minutes later, the Panther circles the landing pad.

“Scorpio air traffic control, this is unregistered merchant ship, permission to land”, Rodgers lies over his microphone.

“Ok then”, he says pushing the controls forward for a landing.

“Did they say something”, you ask not having heard a reply.

“Nope…I think it’s safe to assume there is no air traffic control facility here.”

Having selected an open launch pad, your ship hangs in a slowly descending hover until it touches down,
“Ok”, you start. “I’m going to do a quick recon of the area. Buck, I want you to stay here and be ready if we need to do a quick lift-off or if we need a pickup. Stephanie, you also stay here. A medical officer is too valuable at this stage of the game to put in the line of fire.”

Looking at Spengler and Spencer, you’re not sure which one to take with you on your recon. You are certain that you will need a pair of eyes to watch your back, but you also want to leave a security force on the ship, and Spengler packs a mean punch.

Who will you take with you?
111.title: Hector-Prime

1111.content:
“Spengler, you’re on me”, you say having decided that Spengler is the man you want watching your back.

The two of you stand in the back of the ship as the cargo ramp whines open. The hot humid air of Hector-Prime fills the hold. Spengler is wearing a heavy leather trench coat to hide the light assault rifle he decided to take along. You are wearing a civilian coverall, with you Gauss pistol strapped to your belt.

You smell spices and food, their odour drifting up from the street bazaars. You also smell the distinct odour of Silk.

As you leave the ship, you see a bar at the opposite end of the strip of launch pads. A wooden carved sign reads ‘The Jungle Room’.

“Let’s check that place out”, you say to Spengler and the two of you make your way over. Having an Orion Commando at you back, does put you at ease. Knowing that Spengler could single-handedly clear out the bar if he has to, is good to know.

Checking your watch, which is connected to the ship’s central computer, you press the ‘Local Time’ button.

“Ten forty five a.m. and the bar is in full swing”, you say with a smile. “These are party-people.”

Spengler doesn’t comment as the two of you walk in through the saloon -style swing doors. The inside is dark and a thick could of smoke hangs under the ceiling. A number of scruffy characters dot the tables. The bar is hot and the smell of many years of spilled drinks and stale alcohol fills your nostrils.

In the far corner you see an Ar-Kwan alien sitting in one of the corners.

(A large and usually peaceful specimen, the Ar-Kwan originates from uncharted space beyond the outer rim. Having found the human occupied reaches of the Universe in complete disarray and saturated with war, they showed no interest in further interaction with humans.

Their bodies resemble the humanoid shape, but their faces look reptilian. Their hides are formed by layers of scales making them very resilient to high temperatures. As with earthly reptilians, they also don’t cope with cold temperatures very well. When amongst humans, they also dress typical humanoid garbs, but it is said that they have no need for clothing when on their home planet.

Except for a small number that trade and travel in human occupied space, they are for the most part, rarely seen.)

In the background, a lazy tune contributes to the laid-back, if somewhat ominous feeling in the bar.

“Two of those”, you say walking up to the counter, pointing at the house brew. The fat, bald bar tender expertly grabs two glasses and fills them with green liquid from the ‘house’ vat.

“You sure about this”, Spengler asks nodding at the drinks.

“We gotta blend in if we want to get a feel for the place”, you say easily.

“Bottoms up”, you say and take a big swing. The bitter green liquid is cool and strangely refreshing. After more than three days of battle stress on the America, you don’t see anything wrong with a tiny bit of R&R while still doing your job.

Within a few seconds, you feel the buzz of the ‘house brew’.

“What’s on your mind?” you ask Spengler, seeing that he hasn’t touched his drink.

“Well, if it’s Pylene we’re after, I’m thinking we should talk to the Ar-Kwan”, he replies. “The only reason he can be here is for trading – he’s definitely not a tourist. And seeing that he’s a trader, he will have some connections for getting Pylene.”

“What about the barman”, you ask.

“I suppose”, Spengler says scanning the bar with his steely eyes.

“You’re right”, you respond. “The Ar-Kwan is the best option.”

Taking your drink, you lead the way to the Ar-Kwan’s table.

“Mind if we sit for a moment”, you ask looking into his black beady eyes.

“I have no business with you”, he hisses, apparently not needing a translation module.

“Your English is good”, you counter. “So you’ll have no problem understanding me when I say that you will be losing out on a large profit margin if you deny our business.”

“I have more than enough business. I don’t need you wasting my time”, he says dismissively.

111111.content:
“This bozo won’t sell us any Pylene. Let’s get out of here,” you say to Spengler.
“Did you say Pylene”, the Ar-Kwan asks.
“Yeah, that’s right,” you answer. “But like you said, you have more than enough business, so we’re leaving.”
“I happen to have my hands on some surplus Pylene,” the Ar-Kwan responds. “ How much do you need?”
“We need thirty tons...and we need it now,” you reply. “We can pay in either OEA- or Guhl credits...or we can make an electronic transfer to your bank of choice.”
“Hah, my bank of choice”, the Ar-Kwan smirks. “I’ll take it all in Guhl credits...it seems they’re gonna win the war.”
“Sure, whatever,” you say slightly perturbed by his comment. “How much do you want per ton?” you ask.

“Ten thousand Guhl credits per ton...that adds up to three hundred thousand Guhl credits,” he says taking another swing of his drink.

“Are you insane,” you counter. “That’s ten times the commercial rate. We’ll give you half that.”

“Good luck on finding any Pylene on this planet,” he says easily, sipping his drink again. “You guys are shit-out-of-luck...and my price is ten-thousand credits per ton.”

You realise bargaining with the Ar-Kwan will get you nowhere. And since you’re not spending your own money, you decide to pay him.

“Ok fine,” you reply. “Where do we pick up our Pylene?”

“Well, that’s the thing,” he hisses. “It’s held up in one of my camps in the jungle and we can’t fly in to pick it up...we’re gone have to drive in to get it. Rival factions have a network of anti-aircraft turrets that will shoot us down if we fly in.”

You realise that your stealth-ship could easily negotiate the anti-aircraft stations, but at the same time you cannot reveal the nature of your ship to the Ar-Kwan. You know he will sell the information to any willing buyer, especially since a ship like that is a very rare commodity...and if the Guhl learns of your presence, the mission is over.

Looking around, you see a convoy of old trucks approach along a winding gravel road. The convoy stops in front of you and you recognise the Ar-Kwan in the front truck.

112.content:
“Let’s head for Echo-Centauri”, you say confidently. “It’s probably the last place anybody would expect us – in the midst of the enemy...also, we’ll be playing to our strength with our stealth abilities.”

“Rodger that, captain”, Buck says as he configures the navigation computer to head for Echo-Centauri. “Hold on everyone...here we go...” with that the sip smoothly transitions to warp speed.

“Approaching Echo-Centauri,” Rodgers says. “Initiating warp drive shut down,” he continues focussing on the controls in front of him.

Seconds later, the galaxy containing Echo-Centauri flashes into view. The ship zooms in on a green and brown planet, the gravity regulator of the ship making the approach and stop effortless.

“Computer,” you say, “planet statistics please.”

“Planet: Echo-Centauri,” the computer complies.
“Atmosphere composition: 78.91% nitrogen, 21.85% oxygen, 0.83% argon, 0.38% carbon dioxide, remainder – trace elements. Atmosphere, breathable.
Temperature: 25 to 35 degrees Celsius.
Climate: low to high rainfall, humidity 5% to 80%
Geology: Sand consisting of Silica, Quartz and limestone with high levels of organic deposits
Vegetation: Desert to Jungle
Life: Various life forms detected
Structures: Numerous clusters of structures detected, mostly mining of military – all structures belonging to the Miras-Guhl.
General: Planet’s geology, climate and atmosphere almost identical to that of Old Earth.”

“Ok”, you say rubbing your chin. “What we’ll do is patrol one of the main transport routes on the surface. Once we have identified a Pylene transporter, we’ll take it down, scavenge the Pylene supplies and stock up. Our stealth cover should enable us to do so undetected. Then we’ll do a quick airborne strike on a mining facility, obviously also under stealth cover, and acquire the needed mining tools and then we’ll be out of here...any questions?”

The crew looks at you with bland expressions, seemingly unimpressed with the simplicity of your plan.

“Crew”, Buck says easily, “prepare for atmosphere entry.”

With that he directs the ship towards the planet below. Soon the ship shoots like a burning meteor into the planet’s atmosphere.

Dropping below the light cloud cover, you see green jungle speeding past on the planet’s surface.

“Right Buck”, you instruct your second in command. “Set a course for a transport route between two of the major military and mining facilities. Let’s see if we can find a Pylene transporter.”

“We seem to be in luck sir”, Buck replies. “We have a Pylene transporter up ahead with a single escort. The payload should be in the order of twenty tons. Shall we proceed?”

“Yes”, you reply. “Approach the target from behind and engage. I want you to track the escort and dispense of him using a Viper missiles. Then we can take the transporter down with the Reaper-cannon. That way we don’t blow the Pylene to dust.”

“Rodger”, is all Buck says before engaging the weapons system. He starts tracking the bogey. A schematic image of the enemy escort, known as a Wasp, appears on your screen. It’s sleek lines and deadly weapons combinations make it the premier fighter in the Guhl inventory.

“Missile lock”, he says. “Firing now...missile away.”

Before the missile hits the Wasp escort, you see it diving and dodging wildly. It must have seen the incoming missile. Fortunately it too late and the missile tear the enemy escort apart.

“Now for the transporter”, you say. “Activate the reaper cannon.”

Tracking the transporter, the Reaper cannon starts firing accompanied by a load buzz. Energy rounds extend a trail up to the transporter and then tears into its rear. The tail fins of the boxy transport ship are ripped apart. Black smoke erupts from the ship and it starts losing altitude rapidly. Dropping down it plummets into the jungle below.

“They never had a chance”, you say proudly tapping your armrest, your pride of the Black Panther clearly visible on your face.

“Now let’s drop down and get that Pylene”, you continue.

Buck complies and swings the ship around to land at the crash site.

“We’re receiving a priority message on a secure frequency, sir”, science officer Spencer says from behind.

“Put it on”, you reply surprised to be receiving any type of transmission at this stage. Who could possible know you’re on this Guhl-invested planet?

“Star Destroyer Liberty, this is Admiral Ortega. Commence bombing run of Echo-Centauri.”

“What the hell...did I hear right”, you ask in complete shock. “Did he say bombing run of ECHO-CENTAURI?”

“Must be a black-op”, Orion command Spengler says dryly. “Otherwise admiral Zane would have told us to avoid Echo-Centauri.”

“Shit”, you say bitterly. “Everything was going so well. If they do a bomb run on this planet with a Star Destroyer, our best chance is to land this ship and ride it out...even then we’ll only have a ten percent chance of survival.”

“We can also try and clear the atmosphere before the bomb run starts”, Buck proposes.

“Yes, but if we’re in the air when the low-altitude-detonation anti-matter ordinance is dropped we have a zero percent chance of survival”, you counter.

1121.content:
“I saw a valley a few miles back”, you say urgently. “If we land in the valley, the surrounding ridges might shield us from the blows.”

Buck swings the ship around and activates the afterburners. The green jungle flies past below the ship. Reaching the valley, he flies lower and slows to a hover before descending in between the trees.

As the branches and leaves reach up from below, it scratches over the surface of the ship. The ship bucks and shakes as it breaks through the trees.

“Just keep going”, you say to Buck. “We don’t have any other option.

“Bomb run commencing in thirty seconds”, you hear the radio announce.

“Activate all shields”, you command.

“All shields activated”, the computer complies.

Breaking through the final few feet of underbrush, the ship touches down. A moment later you see a bright flash from outside.

“Buckle up everyone”, you say. “This might get nasty.”

From outside, you hear what sounds like a thunderstorm rolling in. Shockwaves shake the trees.

“Sounds like a real shit-storm that’s blowing in”, commando Spengler says.

Ker-whump...Ker-Whump...KER-WHUMP

The ship starts shaking. Panels pop off from the control consoles. Electrical fires erupt and alarms start blaring.

“Shields compromised...” is all you hear the ships’ computer announce before it’s drowned out by the noise.

KER-WHUMP...KER-WHUMP...KERR-WHUUMP

Straining against your seat belt, you are certain the next round will either destroy the ship or flip it over on its roof.

Outside you see waves of leaves, dust and branches bounce of the shields.

At least the shields are still somewhat active, you think to yourself. For what seems like an eternity, it feels like the entire world around you is being torn apart. The shaking and noise gets so bad, you are not certain if you’re still upright, upside down or even alive.

The deafening noise starts getting softer, replaced by a ringing sound in your ears. The shaking gets less, until finally, you hear it getting softer in the distance. Shaking your head and blinking, you focus on the chaos around you. You can see the ship’s computer is still talking by its blinking light, but all you hear is the ringing in your ears.

Smoke fills the cockpit with scattered fires and sparks in various locations. Feeling something wet run down the side off your face, you run your finger over it and look at it. Red blood stains your finger tips and you realize it is coming from your ear.

You see at least two of your crew members are unconscious.
1121.title: Land the ship and wait out the bomb run

11211.content:
You release the clip on your seat belt, seeing the two members you thought were unconscious start to move.

Looking out the porthole, you can see the landscape beyond the valley. It resembles a wasteland of craters.

“Holy shit”, you whisper. “Planet FUBARed”.

“Here comes the cavalry” Spengler says from behind.

Overhead you see what looks like a swarm of insects. Then you realise the dark cloud is a massive formation of OEA troop and equipment carriers commonly called Mules. The Mule is a type of drop-ship used on planetary assaults. One Mule can typically carry one hundred soldiers or three heavy combat vehicles such as a Centurion tank.

“Activate our distress beacon”, you say. “Let’s make sure they don’t mistake us for an enemy craft and call for an air strike.”

“Activated”, the computer complies.

"Computer", you say, "give me a damage report."

“Stealth system – damaged and deactivated", the computer starts.
"Engines damaged and deactivated at twenty percent capacity;
Shields – damaged and deactivated;
Auxiliary power – hundred percent remaining;
Ship’s hull – intact, functional at ninety percent capacity;
Avionics – functional at fifty percent capacity, navigation accuracy compromised;
Primary power source – functional at twenty percent capacity;
Weapons systems – functional at hundred percent capacity.”

"We're not going anywhere untill we get at least five repair droids out here", you say dryly.

As the Mule drop ships scatter out over the landscape, one lands fifty feet from your position. You see the cargo ramp open, followed by a stream of heavy infantry pouring out the back. In front, you recognise the platoon sergeant by his rank. He heads over to your position.

“Open the ramp”, you say making sure your Gauss pistol is loaded before running down the ramp.

“Sergeant”, you say saluting the approaching soldier.
11211.title: You release the clip on your seat belt...

choices: “ No way son, we’re staying here – you send the droids when you’ve taken VR-
112111.content:
“I am Captain Jack Gunn of the 110th expeditionary division of the 9th star fleet on high priority assignment by Admiral Zane”, you say as he approaches.

“I am Sergeant Donald Metcalf of the 22nd mechanised infantry on high priority assignment by Admiral Ortega”, the sergeant replies coyly.

“Fair enough sergeant”, you reply. “We all have a job to do, but I can assure you my mission is of utmost importance and I will need your assistance to repair my ship and continue onwards.”

“Sorry sir, we’re not going anywhere until we’ve secured Echo-Centauri. I’ve been sent to investigate your presence here. We were told there are no OEA personnel on the planet…you can be lucky we didn’t just call in an air strike.”

“Right”, you say, realizing you’ve just encountered a major delay on your mission.

“So what do we do now sergeant”, you ask, knowing you are now the last priority on a long ‘to-do-list’ that is being run by some infantry commander.

“Well”, he starts, not sounding entirely sure. “Now you come with us…we’ll have to leave your ship here. We’re on our way to the front line to take a Guhl base known as VR-101. Once that is secured, we’ll be resupplied and can possibly arrange for repair droids to be delivered to your ship.”

“We can’t stay with out ship”, you ask, not really wanting to join the grunts on their mission to the front line.

“Well”, Metcalf replies, “we’ve received reports that the Guhl dispatched search-and-destroy patrols once the bomb run stopped and if they find you, you’re dead meat.”

What do you do next?
112111.title: I am Captain Jack Gunn ...

choices: You realize you are in a fight for your life...
1121111.content:
“Ok sergeant, lead the way”, you say. “Just let me get my men.”

Before you can run up the ramp of your ship, a massive explosion sends you flying. Crashing into the ground ten feet from where you were standing, you shake your head and look up to see a Guhl search-and-destroy patrol coming down the slopes of the valley.

Metcalfe and his men jump into action, firing their Gladiator assault rifles.
(You’ve always liked the Gladiator assault rifle. Unlike the Jackhammer used by the marines, it’s not an energy weapon. It fires synthetically augmented alloy rounds that is claimed to have much more penetrative power than energy rounds. In general, it resembles a heavy machine gun, but with much more punch than the ones used on Old Earth way back when. In addition, it is fitted with a mechanised spike-teethed bayonet that extends past the barrel. When activated the blade vibrates at supersonic speed and can cut through most types of armour,)

With the machine guns pouring fire on the approaching Guhl, you scramble to your feet and run back into your ship. Cling-clang noises echo through the ship as bullets bounce off it.

“Grab your shit”, you scream over the gunfire. “We’re leaving!”

Leading the way down the ramp, your crew follows in staggered trail formation, everybody hunched over.

Wielding your Gauss pistol, you take a few pot shots as you run. Diving for cover behind a rock formation, you see Spengler grabbing a Gladiator from a fallen soldier. He ducks in beside you and fires over the rock.

His first burst of fire hits two approaching Guhl in the chest. His second spray takes down another one. He’s definitely Special Forces, you think to yourself.

Not being a trench soldier yourself, you decide to follow his lead as he makes his way to the line of infantry men fighting off the Guhl.

A cloud of dust puffs up as you fall down next to him and fire three rounds with your pistol in rapid succession. You realise you’ve lost the rest of your crew. No time to regroup now, you think as bullets zip over your head.

“Use this”, Spengler says as he throws you an assault rifle taken from another dead soldier.
1121111.title: “Ok sergeant, lead the way.”

choices: “Cover me Spengler, I’ll pilot the Mule and go pick up a tank.”
“Spengler, can you fly a Mule? I’ll cover you! Go get us a tank!”
11211111.content:
The powerful Gladiator kicks you in the chest as you squeeze the trigger, a stream of tracers kicking up sand in front of the approaching Guhl.

“Dagger-one, Dagger-one, this is Dagger-five”, you hear Metcalfe call over his helmet mounted radio. “We are in contact with one Guhl search-and destroy element. Request reinforcements…request reinforcements...what’s your ETA…roger, I see you.”

Following Metcalfe’s gaze, you see a single Mule approaching low over the valley ridge. Your eye catches a smoke trail reaching up from the Guhl forces. You realize it’s an anti-aircraft missile seconde before it tears the Mule apart in a ball of flame.

“Shit”, Metcalfe swears before firing another burst over the rock face. “Dagger-two, Dagger-two, this is Dagger-five…we need reinforcements…watch out for antiaircraft missiles…are you reading my location…shit.”

“Look alive everyone”, Metcalfe screams over the gunfire. We’re on our own on this one. No-one’s flying in here with those anti-aircraft missiles out there.”

Realizing that no reinforcement will reach you within time, you renew your efforts with the Gladiator. Taking aim over the gun sight, you squeeze the trigger again and steer the trail of bullets over an approaching enemy. He falls head over feet.

Looking around, you see approximately eighty men fighting back the Guhl which seem to be at least double in numbers.

“If we had a single Centurion tank, we’d rip them a new one you hear Metcalfe say to his Corporal.”

Looking at the Mule that brought Metcalfe and his team in, you realise the pilots have long since been shot.

Your eyes meet Spengler’s. You see he is thinking the same thought.

What do you do next?
11211111.title: You realize you are in a fight for your life...

choices: You decide to join Metcalfe. “Welcome to the Infantry, sir.”
“No thanks, sergeant. You guys attract trouble like flies to a turd.”
112111111.content:
“Cover me Spengler, I’ll pilot the Mule and go pick up a tank”, you say, not believing what you are doing.

Jumping up, you run for the Mule with all your strength. Bullets fly past and it feels like time slows down. Ten feet from the open ramp, you dive head first into the open cargo door. Executing a perfect roll, you hit the floor running and slide in behind the controls, stepping over the dead pilot.

Bullet holes riddle to cockpit window. Quickly you flick various power switches on and fire up the engines. Looking back over your shoulder, you see Spengler giving the Guhl hell through the open cargo door.

The ship lifts off blowing up a thick cloud of dust.

Pressing the controls forward, the hovering ship tilts over and speeds away. Sweat pearls on your forehead as the expectation of an anti-aircraft missile up your tailpipe flash through your head. Then you slip over the valley ridge and away from the deadly reach of the Guhl missiles. You breathe a sigh of relief.

Checking the navigation computer, you see the location of a tank platoon close by, with a unit name of Dragon-61.

“Dragon 61, Dragon 61, this is Dagger-five” you say using Metcalfe’s call sign. “We’re in contact with the asshole-squad and need some assistance…standby for a single tank pick-up”, you finish not wanting to waste the time of picking up three tanks.

“Roger Dagger-five”, you hear the platoon leader comply. “One tank standing by for your pick-up.”

Seconds later you land in front of the tank formation. As you touch down a Centurion tank rumbles up the ramp.

(A nasty piece of armament, the Centurion tank is famous for wreaking havoc and sowing mass destruction when operated by an experienced crew. With gigantic fibre reinforced wheels allowing all-terrain mobility, its rapid-fire main gun can expel three high explosive slugs per second complemented by two powerful mini-guns.)

“All systems are five-by-five”, the tank commander says with a heavy cowboy-drawl over the radio. “Point us in the right direction and we’ll unleash hell.” You smile and return your eyes to the front.

Pulling the Mule up, you engage the afterburners and speed back to the valley. Within minutes you pass over the valley’s ridge and approach the battlefield.

“No missiles, please, no missiles”, you whisper, again sweating profusely. An alarm starts blaring. Then you see a smoke trail reach up from the ground. A shot of adrenaline flushes through your system. Banking the Mule hard, you release countermeasures. The missile streaks closer…then it passes by harmlessly - confused by the countermeasures you released.

Closing in on ground zero, you swing the ship around and land.

“Yee-haw”, you hear as the Centurion launches out the cargo hold, guns flaring. Over the radio you can hear the tank commander calmly directing his gunners and driver. Looking back you enjoy the spectacle as high explosive shells rain over the enemy. Within minutes, the battlefield is a crater riddled patch of scorched earth.

“Good job, Captain”, you hear Metcalfe say over the radio, clearly relieved. “You saved our hides today.”

Getting out of your chair, your coveralls are drenched in nervous sweat. You walk down the ramp and breathe easily. It feels like a weight has been lifted from your shoulders.

“I’m afraid I have bad news, Captain”, Metcalfe says as he approaches. “Except for Commander Spengler, the rest of your crew has been eliminated…I’m sorry.”

Metcalfe gives you a few seconds to digest the news before continuing. “We’ve received reports from the frontline. Apparently losses were high due to mobile anti-aircraft crews – just like the one that was part of this search-and-destroy patrol. Apparently the bomb run was not as effective as we had hoped. We will not have to approach VR-101 on foot. You and Commander Spengler should join us…but it remains your decision, sir.”

113.content:
“Head for Procol Kilia”, you say. “I’ve heard of it before and I like the idea that it’s not dominated by anyone – we’ll just step carefully to avoid the spies. I’m confident that this state-of-the-art craft can handle whatever this Houston-Knox field throws at us.”

With that Buck punches in the coordinates and engages the warp drive. “Warp drive engaged”, he says calmly. “Approaching the field...entry within fiv...four...three...two...one...”

Outside a blue cloud envelops the ship. All instruments read normal.

“I think we’re ok”, you say before the ship starts shaking violently. A variety of alarms start blaring.

“Hull stress at seventy percent and climbing fast”, Buck screams over the noise. “External energy flux is draining our shields...shield capacity at eighty percent and falling...”

“Engage flight stabilizers”, you scream.

As the flight stabilizers engage, the shaking of the ship reduces.

“Sir”, Buck yells, “the hull stress is at one hundred percent and the shield capacity has fallen to twenty percent...we can activate the auxiliary power source and redirect it to the shields...but that means we won’t have backup power if we experience and emergency later...what do we do?”
113.title: Procol-Kilia

1131.content:
“Engage auxiliary power”, you yell. “And direct the spare capacity to the shields!”

You see the auxiliary power light blink on, on your console.

“Shields at fifteen percent”, Buck yells again. “Shields at twenty percent and climbing...shields stabilizing at thirty percent...”

On your console, you can see the shields sucking the power from the auxiliary source. The power levels are dropping rapidly.

“Auxiliary power depleted”, Buck yells. “Shields at twenty five percent and dropping.”

“SHIT!” you scream with frustration.

“Warning, warning”, the computer announces, “shields are failing; hull pressure at one-hundred-and-twenty percent capacity.”

You realize that you’re going to die. It’s over...

“Emerging from Houston-Knox field”, the computer announces. The ship stops shaking. “Arrival at Procol-Kilia”, the computer says again.

You see a red and black lava encrusted planet appear in front of you.

“Holy shit”, you exclaim, happy to be alive.

Small electrical fires sparkle all over the cockpit. You look around at the crew. Spencer is suffering from a bleeding head wound. The rest of the crew seems dazed and confused, except for the Orion Commando named Spengler.

“That was a helluva ride”, he says with a crooked smile.

“Officer Cook”, you say to the medical officer, “tend to Spencer’s head wound. Buck, run a diagnostics check on the ship.”

As Stephanie Cook runs over to Malcolm Spencer, the computer starts giving feedback on the ship’s condition:
“Stealth system – damaged and deactivated;
Engines functional at forty percent capacity;
Shields – damaged and deactivated;
Auxiliary power – zero percent remaining;
Ship’s hull – two hairline fractures incurred, functional at fifty percent capacity;
Avionics – functional at fifty percent capacity, navigation accuracy compromised;
Primary power source – functional at twenty percent capacity;
Weapons systems – non functional due to power shortage.”

“Well, at least we’re alive”, you say. “Buck, request permission to land. We’ll reassess on landing-pad and decide what to do next.”
1131.title: Activate auxiliary power and direct to shields!

1132.content:
“We can’t waste our auxiliary power now”, you scream. “We ride it out!”

As you finish your last word, the shaking worsens.

“Shields at zero percent...hull pressure at one-hundred-and-ten percent”, Buck yells.

Electrical fires erupt from the control panels accompanied by smoke. Another shake slams Medical Officer Cook’s head into her console. She appears to be unconscious.

“Warning, warning”, the computer announces. “Ship at critical levels of exposure.”

“Ok”, you relent. “Start up the auxiliary power and redirect it to the shields!”

A thundering explosion throws the ship head over heels. As the hull starts failing, you hear what sounds like a loud moan. You realise it is the hull that is cracking.

“Warning, warning, hull at one-hundred-and-forty percent capacity...shields deactivated...auxiliary power source compromised...”

‘Compromised?’ you think to yourself...‘what the hell does that mean.’

“I don’t think we’re gonna make it”, is the last thing you hear Buck scream before you’re consumed in a ball of fire.

THE END (PS. please review!)

12.content:
You step onto the ship and from its features you can tell it is battle-ready. Walking past you crew you salute them and scan their faces.

First in line you see the six space marines. Re-conditioned convicts, the marines are tough as nails and you can see it on their faces. Battle scars and tattoos riddle their bodies and not getting your salute returned doesn’t surprise you much. Their heavy-assault rifles, known as “Jackhammers” are stacked up next to them.

The Tiger-Cat units are strapped in with their operators standing beside them. Tiger-Cats are tough little bastards, and you’ve seen them in action more than once. Approximately seven feet in height, they resemble mechanised walker units with two mini-guns for arms. Being able to withstand heavy small-arms fire, they can wreak havoc in infantry units. Seeing that their operators are in their thirties, comforts you. In your experience, young, inexperienced soldiers have the tendency to get people killed.

Behind them, you find the two heavy assault Rhino’s. Being the big brothers of the Tiger-Cats, the Rhino’s are approximately three times the size of the Tiger-Cats. For transport purposes, they can fold-up to fit into the interceptor’s hull. Except for a set of mini-guns similar to that of the Tiger-Cats, their weapons systems further include medium-sized cannons and anti-aircraft guns. Their operators are Sergeants Tombs and Spears, and by the enemy units painted on the sides of their units, you can tell they’ve been around the block a couple of times.

The science officer, medical officer and engineer seem very skittish as you pass them. Checking and re-checking their seat-belts, you can tell they’ve never served in a combat zone before – not a quality that you appraise very highly.

As you enter the cockpit, Sergeant Rico looks up at you. Saluting you, he gets up to shake your hand. In his eyes you can see he is a man you can trust. His handshake is firm, and his smile honest.

“Pleasure to serve with you sir,” he says as he sits down and continues his pre-flight checklist.

Strapping yourself in, you find the ship prepared and ready for take-off.

Two minutes later, you are forced back into your seat as you shoot from the port of the Star Destroyer America, slipping into open space.

“Ready for warp-speed transition”, Sergeant Rico announces.

“We can head straight for our target sir. Although, as you know, we might need to pick up mining equipment first. Therefore, we have two choices; firstly, shall we head straight for the destination, or shall we head to the mining centre on the planet called Kepler? Kepler has fortifications of the Miras-Guhl, and we might get some resistance, although showing up at our destination without mining tools could provide us with a serious problem.
12.title: F-204 Scythe long range interceptor

choices: Update the Status of other Vessels
121.content:
Without hesitation you sternly reply, "I believe the 9th fleet is depending on our victory and it should be swift! Warp speed immediately to lessen our detection…and continue on through quadrant E9. I dispatched drones through those sectors just a short time ago – they showed all clear. We should proceed safely and without being noticed."

Visibly startled, Sergeant Rico requests clarification, "Do we need to obtain Admiral Zane's approval before I adjust the appropriate coordinates?"

"Absolutely not!" you reply firmly. “I am mission-commander, Sergeant. Zane informed me that our scientists had a reading from Xelesor which is what this mission is for and it's our goal to find the material, no matter what it takes! So be prepared for a fight with the Miras-Guhl if necessary."

Nodding in agreement, Rico flips up the cover to expose the track of blinking lights.

"We are ready to engage, Sir. Warp-speed transition locked - ON. Hold steady, now!"

Bracing their arms in place, the crew anticipates a steady increase in speed, however the jolt of power nearly makes it impossible to adjust their heads to a more comfortable position. A brief surge, and the F-204 Scythe is cruising at its' maximum speed.

“We’re a couple of hours from our destination,” you say looking at your crew. “I expect a full report from each section before we get there.”


Mere moments after sitting down in your chair, the engineer, Thomas Eldersen approaches you.

"Sir, some of the emergency exit lights went out when we were thrust into warp-speed. It causes me concern because the circuits are interconnected with the limited stealth features and the science laboratory."

Casting a glance to your science officer, you wait for confirmation that all electrical outlets are in working order. Without being asked the science officer responds, "Sir, nothing here seems to be out of the ordinary. I will run a diagnostic check to verify the laboratory is working as it should be."

Relieved, you sit back in your chair. "What, if any, problems encountered with warp-speed do you have to report from the medical section Dr Jacobs?"

"No injuries here, Sir!" Jacobs replies, seemingly happy with his section.

For a moment you sit in silence. What could go wrong with the stealth and cloaking appliances if Eldersen is right, you wonder.

Snapping back to the present, you address your crew. "Listen up everyone, I need your feedback," you request without specifically addressing anyone in the group.

"The signal emitted from Xelesor system is strong. Does anyone here have experience working with the material we're looking for?"

"Yes Sir, We do, Sir!" three of the six space Marines respond.

If I only get three then I can work with that, you think to yourself sighing with relief.

“I want the three of you to enter as much as you know into that database right now. It will scan each of the planet surfaces for material already found and compile a tracking order for us to update. Other information will be forthcoming from Admiral Zane. The rest of you get to work, we don't have all day."

Swivelling your chair around, you face Rico. "Sergeant Rico, what's the status of the HR-122 Black Panther stealth ship, the CLK-800 Juggernaut prospector and the Freelancer 2200? We may need their assistance if they are within our sector and have the ability to offer current information about the Miras-Guhl."
121.title: The Destination

choices: Go down the mine shaft and shut the miners up for good
Prepare for an attack from the Guhl
Try to get the equipment out before the enemy arrives
122.content:
“Approaching Kepler,” Rico says. “Initiating warp drive shut down,” he continues, focussing on the controls in front of him.

The ship slips from warp drive to cruising speed and a red-brown planet materializes in front of you.

“Planet: Kepler,” the computer announces.
“Atmosphere composition: 78.91% nitrogen, 21.85% oxygen, 0.83% argon, 0.38% carbon dioxide, remainder – trace elements. Atmosphere, breathable.
Temperature: 30 to 55 degrees Celsius.
Climate: no rainfall, humidity 0%
Geology: Sand consisting of Silica, Quartz and limestone
Vegetation: None – Desert landscape
Life: Subsurface life forms detected, human life forms detected in surface structures
Structures: Seven clusters of structures detected ranging from small to medium – The three largest ones are military under the control of Miras-Guhl, the smaller ones are all mines.”

“Ok”, you say. “Our basic cloaking system should buy us enough time to land at one of the mines and get what we need before the Guhl scanners descramble the signal. Science officer, how much time do we have?”

“By my calculations we should have approximately on hour before they start tracking us sir”, the Science officer replies over the intercom system.

“That doesn’t leave us with much time”, you whisper.

“Head for the nearest mine”, you instruct.

Rico sets the navigation computer and the Scythe slips though the sky.

“E.T.A. five minutes, sir”, Rico replies. “I’m engaging the jammers so that they can’t send a may-day to the military bases when they see us.”

“All military units, stand by”, you say over your mike.
“When we hit the ground, I want you to disembark in combat formation. I want the Rhino’s to take the lead and pop through the fence. There you stop and cover our approach. The two Tigercats will follow and lead the way to the main building. Three marines stay with the ship. The other three press through and secure the entrance to the main building at the service entrance. You open the doors from inside and the two Tigercats go in and secure the workshop. Once all is clear, we adios the equipment we need. Any questions?”

With no questions you continue, “Remember, these miners are Miras-Guhl. We shouldn’t encounter much more than light gunfire resistance, but keep your eyes open and watch your backs.”

Five minutes later the Scythe blows up clouds of dust as it settles onto the flat plain at the edge of a small mining facility. In a distance the sun is approaching the horizon and you realise it will set within the hour.

The facility is simple, with four small structures scattered around a larger main building. The main building has a massive tower stretching into the sky above it. The entire facility is surrounded by a low-tech fence. The scythe touches down just outside the fence.

Standing in the cargo hold with a small pulse rifle and light body armour, you watch the mechanised units and marines with anticipation. As the cargo ramp touches the ground, the first Rhino steps onto the desert sand. Seconds later its cannon fires and a sentry tower close by explodes. The second Rhino unit is close behind the first. You see it paining the communications tower with its laser designator before it too fires its cannon destroying the tower.

The Rhinos pan out and walk towards the fence, their footsteps accompanied by the signature sound as the mechanics in their legs work. The TigerCats step out behind them. They also start firing short sporadic bursts at security personnel. Empty shells pour out the sides of their arms as their six-barrel mini guns buzz angrily.

The Rhinos easily trample the fence and hold position, still searching for targets. The TigerCats walk past them and approach the main building. Moments before they stop, three of the marines run from the Interceptor. As always, you are amazed at how fast they can move while wearing the bulky mechanized armour.

Running up to a personnel door, one of the marines fires his Jackhammer. The heavy weapon coughs once, obliterating the door in a thousand pieces. The three marines disappear into the building. You hear the muffled sounds of a Jackhammer firing inside the building. Moments later the large service door rolls open. The TigerCats step inside and start firing, tearing the inside of the building apart. You hope they don’t damage any of the mining equipment.

The gunfire stops.

“All clear”, you hear in your earpiece.

With your gun up, you run over to the building with your science officer and engineer in close pursuit. As you run into the mine’s workshop, you find the walls riddled with bullets. A few dead bodies are scattered on the floor. In the centre of the floor, you see a Locator, Mining and Construction Unit or LMCU – exactly what you will need if you want to prospect for shallow to mid-range minerals.

It resembles a massive truck, but one that can deploy to form a drilling rig. With favourable soil conditions it can also act as a subterranean vehicle. In addition to this it has four small drones on the back, each approximately the size of a car. The airborne drones can fly around and hover and with mechanical arms and a range of equipment they can be used to perform various construction and mining tasks.

“Check if all systems are functional and find some spare parts to take along”, you instruct your engineer.

“Sergeant, I want your men to secure the complex for the loading of the equipment”, you say over your mike to the Marine commander. “We have to be out of here in twenty minutes.”

“Check if there is anything else here that might be useful”, you say to your science officer. All seems to be going according to plan. This might just work, you think to yourself.

“Captain, I’m detecting a signal being transmitted from the mine below you”, you hear Rico on your earpiece.

“It seems they are using a fixed line for communication, which means we can’t jam it. If it is linked to one of the military bases, the Guhl is going to be on our asses double quick. I recon we have two minutes before they scramble their birds and another five for them to get here.”

With no time to spare, you realize that you have three options to choose from:
122.title: Kepler

choices: Stand and fight off the fifteen Marines. But they could call for rienforcements.
You could take off and fight them in space. Your ship would probable win but...
Fly off and hope you can outrun them. Those ships look fast though.
1223.content:
"Were stayin’." you say into your mouth piece. "We have seven minutes. Let’s get this crap out of here on the double. Rico, get the equipment ready to board."
"Got it." Rico replies.
You realize that you have to prepare for the worst. “Hurry the hell up”, you bark to your engineer before you turn and exit back into the compound. You need to set up fortifications for the coming storm.
You hear your earpiece crackle to life. "Sir, we got it ready to move. The TigerCats didn't damage it and we got a few spare parts."
"Good." you reply. "Now get it loaded." Good, you think to yourself. We might actually be able to get out of here with the equipment. And alive.
Just as you say this the ground is rent apart ten feet away from you. The Rhino that had been standing there was blasted to pieces. The shock wave throws you back ten feet.
"Sir" Rico shouts in your ear. "They are here. They have engaged."
"So I've noticed Rico. Get the equipment on the ship. Hurry." You look up. Two transport fighter 009's are flying above you. Shield jumps are being thrown and the Marines are already jumping. You count about twenty in all.
"Rico, get ready for some trouble. I count about twenty Marines in all." As you’re speaking, gunfire breaks out. One of your TigerCat starts firing at the falling marines. Two are hit and another wounded before another energy blast wipes the TigerCat from the face of the planet.
"Find cover!" you yell.
"Sir" your engineer's voice comes in through your earpiece. "we’re halfway there sir. We can leave in about two minutes if you can keep the Marines off us."
"Good." you say. "I'll do my best but hurry up." Another boom sounds in the compound. The enemy marines used plasma grenades to blow their own hole in the fence. Three of them come through in triangle formation scouting ahead. You see two snipers covering them from the smashed fence.
You whisper into your mouthpiece."Get me two Marines up here for cover and get a Rhino on the far side of the compound. On my command have the Rhino fire a shell at their hole in the fence. That should block their snipers. Then I want those two Marines to take out the triangle formation. Move!"
A moment later, "were ready sir."
"Fire!" you yell. A screaming bullet comes rocketing out of the sky and blasts between the enemy snipers. One you see is killed instantly and the other is blasted off his feet. Your Two Marines move in and soon the triangle formation is nothing but corpses.
"Sir." your engineer says in your ear."Were ready." Great. You can leave. But what about the fifteen Marines left. They could pursue you in their ships. You’re left with three options.
1223.title: Were Stayin

12231.content:
“With fifteen marines on the ground we’ll draw too much fire, especially if they have mobile anti-aircraft rockets, they can chew through our shields before we get away”, you scream at Rico over your mike.
Thinking to yourself, you quickly calculate what you have left to work with – six marines, one TigerCat and one Rhino.
“Tombs”, you command the last Rhino operator, “Focus all your attention on those birds...get them out of the air. TigerCat-Two, you cover his ass and make sure the marines don’t take him out. Sergeant”, you say to the Marine Commander, “I want you and your men to hold off the approaching marines off as long as you can – I’ve got a plan.” With that you run back to the Scythe. As you run into the open, gunfire rips the ground apart around you. Blue pulses fly past your head. Suddenly you realise that you can be taken out any second by a lucky round.
Looking back over your shoulder, you see the TigerCat opening up on the marines that are firing on you. It’s red tracer rounds kick up a dust could infront of the firing marines and they have to dive for cover. This gives you the precious seconds you need to make the ramp of the Scythe. You run up the ramp and dive inside.

Within seconds you drop in behind the ship’s controls.
“Activate weapons systems”, you command the computer. Outside you see one of the Rhino’s rockets streak towards a Guhl ship. It is consumed in a ball of fire as it hits.
“Good job Tombs”, you say over your mike.

“Weapons activated”, the computer announces. “Choose weapon please.”

Outside you see your Marine Commander and his men take cover as they come under heavy fire. The TigerCat is spitting return fire at the approaching marines, but only enough to keep the Rhino safe as it fires another rocket at the remaining aircraft.

Perfect approach, you think looking at the oncoming marines.

“Vulcan Canon”, you reply to the computer’s question.
A red cross appears on the heads-up display. Quickly you place the headset on. Immediately the red cross on the heads up display follows your head movement to point in the direction you are looking. You aim the red cross directly at the line of marines and press the fire button on your controls. Immediately you can hear a loud roar as the Vulcan cannon erupts outside the ship. A powerful stream of plasma rounds cross the sky between you and the enemy. It cuts the approaching lines to shreds. With a steady hand you walk the fire of the cannon across the enemy line.

Your eye catches another rocket streak across the sky. It obliterates the last Guhl aircraft. Returning your focus to your gunfire, you release the fire button. The area in front of you is left in a cloud of smoke and dust...no movement.

“All fighting units keep on guard. The rest of you, move the LMCU and spare parts onto the ship right now – move!” you command over the airwaves. Remaining in your seat, you scan for remaining targets.

That was a bad hit, you think to yourself. Losing one TigerCat and one Rhino was not part of the plan. At least now you have the equipment you need.

Five minutes later the cargo ramp whines as it closes.

“We’re out of here”, you say to Rico. With that the engines complain as they lift the heavy cargo off the ground and you fly away.

“Man, I’m relieved to be off this dirt ball”, you say to Rico.
“Don’t celebrate just yet”, Rico says. “We’ve got three bogeys following us. They’re too far to fire just yet, but they definitely are following us.”

"Do we launch a decoy into space and land and see if we can mislead them or do we turn and fight?"

Slam on the accelerators and try to jump to warp-drive before they catch you
Turn and fight with the escort
13.content:
The Juggernaut towers in front of you. Not a pretty ship by anyone's standards. It reminds you of a heavily reinforced, space-age wheelbarrow. With two large rocket exhaust openings in the rear and an inverted upward slanting front. It is a heavy and ugly ship and to make matters worse, it is painted a rust-brown colour with bright yellow wing-tip demarcations.

“That must the ugliest piece of s….” you start saying before getting cut off.

“Careful,” a gruff voice says to your left. Turning around, you see a bald headed man with a smouldering cigar in his mouth. “That’s my baby,” he continues.

Wearing an oil stained, tan-coloured tank top, his muscular arms are decorated with a variety of tattoos. A Gauss pistol is strapped to his waist, with extra clips stuffed into the pockets of his cargo pants. A knife is strapped to his right combat boot and a large copper ear-ring hangs from his right ear.

“You must be Betty,” you say, recognising the man from his picture.

“Yeah, I’m Betty,” he replies taking the cigar from his mouth.

“Let’s go Betty. We’ve got work to do.”

Walking up the ramp of the Juggernaut, Betty starts explaining the intricacies of his baby to you.

“She might not be pretty, she might be loud and rugged, and she might not be the fastest ship in the Galaxy, but she’s reliable and she can mine like a sonnofa-bitch.”

“Great” you say as you slide into the co-pilot’s seat.

“The rest of the crew?” you ask.

All the scientists and geeks are housed in the mining and lab area. They checked in long ago – we’re good to go.

“Enough talk,” Betty says. “This bird’s gotta fly.”

Flicking though the switches with expert fingers, you see that Betty knows his ship better than most fleet pilots know theirs. Flicking one switch a couple of times, he waits and then bashes the control panel on the side before the switch blinks on.

“Like I said,” he mumbles, “Reliable.”

Coughing to life in a thick black cloud of smoke, the Juggernaut shudders awake.

Rumbling and growling, Betty taxies her to the launch pad.

“Hear her purr,” he mumbles, clearly in love with his ‘Baby’.

Having changed into a civilian coverall and removed all military issue items from your body, you are ready to gamble your life on this daring mission.

“Pathfinder seven-zero, you are cleared for takeoff. A fighter wing will escort you to your departure point. Good luck.”

With a mock salute, Betty slams the accelerator down, and the Juggernaut roars in protest before launching into open space.

As you clear the America, you see three light fighters drop into formation around you.

“Our baby sitters,” Betty smirks, lighting another cigar.

Within minutes you clear the visual range of the America and find yourselves cruising through open space.

“Hostile aircraft inbound,” the on board computer suddenly announces.

Checking the electronic display, you see a small formation of attack aircraft approaching you from behind.

“Aaah shit, here it starts,” Betty says as he grabs his controls with both hands.

“Arm cannons one and two, shields up” he commands the on board computer.

“Cannons one and two – armed, shield activated” the computer replies.

Flicking on the targeting heads-up display, you see Betty targeting one of your escort planes.

“What the hell are you doing,” you demand as he prepares to fire on your escort.

“Listen Cappy, those are Miras-Guhl Wasps coming from behind. They’re going to rip these jerks a new one, and when they’re finished they’re going to have us for desert. The only way we’re going to survive this is if we convince them that we’re lowly miners being assaulted a group of perky pilots using us for target practise…we can’t outrun them, we can’t fight them, our only option is to try and fool them…”

With that Betty looks at you for your decision.
13.title: CLK-800 Juggernaut  prospector

choices: Fire the tracker into space and head for the Destination
Fly to Kepler and drop the tracker there, before going on
131.content:
“Ok,” you agree reluctantly. “The mission takes priority – let’s try and fool them.”

With that Betty sets his guns to their lowest power setting and opens fire on one of the escort fighters. Bright green plasma rounds cough from guns one and two and streak across the sky towards the first fighter. They explode with a green flash against the fighter’s shields.

Stunned at what had just happened, the pilot wildly jerks his craft up and down to avoid the incoming fire. From his actions you can tell he had no idea he was being fired upond. The three fighters turn in a tight arc.

“Those idiots just realised the Guhl is on our tails…what a bunch of daft wankers,” Betty growls.

Sure enough, you realise that the Juggernaut’s sensors detected the enemy long before the fighters did.

“I bet those assholes thought the fire came from the Guhl’s ships,” Betty continues with a grin, following the tight turn of the escorts.

“Now I’ll fire a couple of rounds at them, making sure I don’t hit them,” Betty says, firing a wild spray of rounds over the escorts as they approach the attacking Wasps.

Within seconds a wild fire fight breaks out. Random rounds streak across the sky and Betty fights his controls, trying to navigate the Juggernaut over, under of away from the cannon fire all around you. Being pulled back and forth in your chair, you get the idea that the wild manoeuvres of your ship must look something like an elephant trying to walk the tightrope.

You realize Betty was right. It saddens you to see the Wasps taking out your escort one by one. As the last ship of the Old Eart Alliance is blown from the sky, the Wasps quickly turn their attention to your prospector ship.

“Now we’ll see if the id-chip your grease-monkeys installed in my ship will fool these assholes,” Betty snarls, puffing a cloud of smoke.

The face of a mean-looking son-of-a-bitch flickers on the screen in front of you.

“Juggernaut, Juggernaut, this is Miras-Guhl Wasp – identify yourself,” you hear in your earpiece.

“Wasp, this is Juggernaut, thanks for saving our tails,” Betty says in a weak voice over the microphone. “We’re private miners on our way to Kepler for supplies when these bastards jumped us. It seems they wanted to use us for target practise…”

Without further warning, you see the Juggernaut’s computer registering a scan on your cargo hold.

“So much for inter-galactic space law,” you say referring to the Guhl’s disregard to ask for permission before scanning your ship. Betty looks at you sideways as if you are speaking an unknown language.

Punching buttons on an electronic box taped to the side of the communications console, Betty busies himself with something.

“Let’s see what the shit-f’r-brains-squad is saying,” he mumbles before hacking in to their closed communications system.

In your ear piece you can hear the Wasp pilots talking. “I’ve never see the Old Earth Alliance attack privates for no reason. I think they’re lying.”

“So what,” another responds. “Who gives a shit why they were firing on each other, at least we know they’re no O.E.A. and the scan confirmed that.”

“Yeah,” the third voice says. “But what do we do with them now?”

“I’d like to blow their asses out of the sky, but we don’t have time to mess around,” the first voice says. “The ninth fleet of the O.E.A. is falling and we need to report back to base…I’ll fire a tracking beacon and report it to Intelligence and that will be that.”

You see Betty is smiling. “The oldest trick in the book,” he says puffing his cigar again. “They think they can stick a tracker on our ass and ‘that will be that.’ Stupid bastards.”

“Get out of this sector and report to Kepler,” the Wasp pilot says again before the formation fires up their engines again, and flies off.

“So how do we disable the tracker,” you ask looking at Betty.

“Well, I happen to have a little gizmo that can do that as well,” he says getting up.

***

Half an hour later, you find yourself in the ship’s laboratory.

“And that is how it’s done,” Betty says very pleased with himself, dropping the tracker on the table. The tracker looks like a metallic disc the size of a saucer.

“Now we need to decide what next, Cappy,” Betty says looking at you.

“We can either attach this to a decoy and shoot it off in space while we keep on course towards the Destination, or we can keep it with us and fly to Kepler and drop it there. Just bear in mind that Kepler is crawling with the Guhl and we’d better have our balls strapped on tight if we’re going to stick our necks in there…”
