132.content:
“Let’s run”, you say. Betty looks at you with a furrowed brow.

“I said get the hell out of here”, you repeat yourself with urgency.

At once Betty turns to his controls and prepares the ship for warp drive. Outside you see plasma rounds passing the ship. A direct hit on one of the escorts sends it up in flames.

“Where are we going,” he yells.

“Anywhere”, you respond.

You notice the fire drawing closer to the Prospector.

“Let’s go”, you scream. “Now!!”

With Betty still punching in coordinates and doing calculations, you realise he’s taking too long. Outside the cockpit you see a blue streak coming from one of the Wasps. A torpedo. You realise you only have seconds.

Without thinking, you slam down the warp drive accelerator, hoping that the auto-navigation system will steer you clear from any obstacles in your path. The ship sputters and coughs and then with a couple of powerful leaps is transitions to warp drive. The last thing you see is the shocked look on Betty’s face as you slip away into the unknown.

Seconds later the ship decelerates, and you slow to a stop.

“What the hell did you do”, Betty asks alarmed, checking the ships status. You’re not sure if he’s upset because you launched the ship into an uncharted course or because he’s afraid of what might have happened to his ‘baby’.

“Computer, track current location”, you say wiping the cold sweat from your forehead.

“Tracking location”, the computer complies and you can see the artificial intelligence light flicker as the ship’s computer tries to figure out where it is.

“Location Unknown”, the computer finally announces.

With confused looks, you and Betty stare at each other.

“I’ve never heard any ship say that before”, Betty says applying himself to the controls again.

“Let me run a quick diagnostics check”, he says.

“Diagnostics check complete”, the computer replies.

“Problem identified in avionics systems… Navigation computer non responsive… Repairs needed…” the computer concludes.

“Aaah Shit”, Betty growls. “Now look what you did…we’re out in the middle of nowhere, with a busted nav-computer. What the hell do we do now?”

“Computer, give me a level five life scan”, you command.

“Cannot comply”, the computer responds.

“This is a mining ship”, Betty says lighting another cigar. “It can’t give you a scan any higher than level three, which means you will only be able to detect life in a three hundred light-year radius…”

“I know what it means”, you say slightly irritated. “Computer, give me a level three life scan”, you try again.

Again you see the artificial intelligence processor working.

“Life detected”, the computer announces, almost with a hint of victory. “Planet unknown…Life specifics unknown…flight time to planet, three seconds at warp speed.”

“Set course for Unknown planet”, you instruct the computer while smiling at Betty.

“What the hell are you smiling at, Cappy? We’re still lost in space with a broken nav-computer…” Biting down on his cigar, Betty fires the ship up and you set off to the Unknown planet. A minute later, you enter a static orbit around the greenish planet.

“Computer, planet statics if you please”, you ask.

“Detecting warning beacon”, the computer replies. “Downloading high priority message from beacon….Message follows: This is a recorded transmission”, you hear the voice over your computer.

“You have reached planet Gefahr. This planet is highly contaminated with various toxins, microbial and radio-active materials following the hundred-year war between the Slooth and the Quasi-Kahr rogue factions of the Miras-Guhl. The planet is under quarantine and entry is strictly prohibited. Further to this, severe contamination of humans remaining on the planet has caused gross mutations. These beings are severely hostile and aggressive. Do not proceed, I repeat, do not proceed to enter the planet’s atmosphere. Transmission ends.”

For a moment there is silence as you and Betty digest what was said.

“Computer, check database for information on planet Gefahr”, you say still feeling a cold shiver up your back.

“Planet: Gefahr,” the computer complies.
“Atmosphere composition: 78.91% nitrogen, 21.85% oxygen, 0.80% argon, 0.32% carbon dioxide, 0.018% strontium-90, 0,002% caesium-137, 0,01% botulins, 0,01% fremolins,0,005% cysozins, 0,005% unidentifiable complex molecules . Atmosphere highly toxic.
Temperature: 5 to 35 degrees Celsius.
Climate: desert landscape
Geology: Sand consisting of Silica, Quartz and limestone
Vegetation: none, all indigenous life on planet is extinct
Life: Small number of human life, Unidentifiable life forms also detected,
Structures: Numerous vacant city centres and military bases.”
History: Planet is best known for the hundred year war that raged between the Slooth and Quasi-Kahr factions. The war raged before the emergence of anti-matter weapons and therefore more conventional weapons of mass destruction for that period was used, all but destroying the planet completely. High levels of biological and hot-particle contamination has caused the planet to be black-listed and it has remained under quarantine for eighty-four years since the end of the war. Survivors are said to live in underground bomb shelters. They come out at times to scavange the wasteland. Due to its reputation, the planet is commonly also referred to as Graveyard, Necropolis and Darkness.”

Looking at Betty, you can tell he shares your thoughts.

“Computer”, you say again, “List closest known planet with life.”

“Closest planet with life is Xannon. It is within range of this ship and our current fuel supply.”

“Computer, with the information at your disposal, can you plot a course for Xannon?”

“Negative, Captain. With the navigation computer out of order, we will not be able to plot a course for Xannon.”

A string of swear words escape Betty’s lips.

“Computer”, you try again, “can you identify the problem with the navigation computer?”

“Yes sir”, the computer responds. “The diagnostics procedure shows that a single component known as a synchropter-chip is unresponsive. This is a common component in many navigation computers for the past hundred years. There is a 84.32% possibility of finding such a chip in any of the derelict war craft on the surface of Gefahr.”

Again you sit in silence.

“What do we have in terms of protective clothing”, you ask Betty.

“I have four mechanised combat-armour suits in the hold with full environmental shielding capacity”, Betty says. “In addition we have four Jackhammer assault rifles and a couple of high explosive grenades.”

“What about surface transport for reconnaissance”, you ask.

“We have a Surface Carrier And Transport or SCAT vehicle that can carry four people. It resembles a golf-cart on steroids and is mostly used for short range expedition.”

Staring at Betty, you see he realizes the inevitable.

“Yeah… let’s go get us a syncropter-chip”, he says as he prepared the ship to enter the atmosphere.

“I’ve never been one to shy away from a challenge”, he says with smoke drifting out of his nostrils.

The Prospector comes to life and leaves its orbit. It accelerates toward the planet until it is consumed in a ball of flame as it enters the atmosphere. Shaking through re-entry, you soon emerge on the other side.

Gefahr is an ugly planet. Miles and miles of desert stretch out in front of you, with a greenish smog filling the atmosphere.

“I’ve detected a city close by. Alternatively there is also a military base”, Betty says. “Which one shall we try first?”
132.title: Slam on the accelerators and try to jump to war...

1321.content:
“Head for the city”, you say as the ship continues over the desert wasteland.

“It must have been the fallout that destroyed all life”, Betty says stating the obvious.

Minutes later, you can see the outline of a metropolis on the horizon. Flying over its massive boundary walls you see it is riddled with dilapidated gun turrets. The streets are empty scattered with rusted car wrecks.

“Head for the city centre”, you say.

“Why don’t we just use the scanners to see if we can locate life”, Betty asks.

“’Cause most if not all of the subterranean bunkers will be shielded for radiation and that means our scanners won’t be able to probe inside...but you can try it for what it’s worth.”

Checking the scanners Betty soon confirms your suspicion. “Yup, countless underground structures, all lined.”

“We’ll drop in the middle somewhere and do some ground recognisance”, you reply. “My guess is that any hardware that was left out there would have been raided by the survivors long ago. So we need to see if we can find life and bargain with them for the required equipment.”

“What if we run into the alleged mutants first”, Betty asks without a hint of nervousness.

“That’s why we’re taking the Jackhammers with and why we’re not stopping unless we find what we’re looking for”, you reply.

You fly in amongst the sky scrapers. A spooky atmosphere hangs over the abandoned city like a thick dark cloud. You wish you didn’t have to get out there and run around in the streets dodging crazed mutants.

“Land over there”, you say pointing to a landing pad surrounded by a razor-mesh fence.

The Juggernaut turns tightly and sinks down on the landing pad, blowing clouds of dust and sand. Betty flicks the controls off and the engines wind down.

Outside, you see the sun in the three o’clock position.

“We should have at least two to three hours of daylight left”, you say. “If we can’t find anything by then, we’ll get back to the ship and go camp out somewhere in the middle of nowhere for the night and try again tomorrow.”

With that, the two of you get up and head for the cargo hold. Without speaking a word, you both put on the mechanised combat armour. The colour of the armour matches the red-brown colour of the Juggernaut. You’re not sure if it is intentional or pure coincidence.

You’ve always been amazed at how light and snug the combat armour was, enabling fast running and easy movements, while providing the mechanised muscle to lift the equivalent weight of a small car.

Loading the Jackhammers, your confidence increases another notch. The weapon fires a heavy-energy round that looks like a blue bolt of light. It can rip though a wall or a car and firing on full automatic, a few well aimed rounds can even pound light-armoured vehicles into submission. Your ammo counter reads five hundred rounds.

Checking the SCAT-vehicle, Betty confirms that it’s fully charged and should give you approximately five hundred miles before needing a recharge. It has four open-air seats and a small cargo hold in the back. On its corners it has four large, heavy tracked all-terrain wheels. You both get in and Betty seals off the rest of the ship, preparing to let the outside air into the cargo hold and lower the cargo door ramp.

The ramp lowers down. The green-grey air fills the cargo hold, and outside the ramp lowers onto the cracked landing pad. Betty starts the engine, and the SCAT vehicle roars to life. With your weapon ready you scan for a threat...but the streets are empty.

A lone tumble weed rolls by in a dry desert gush.

“Let’s go”, you say over the helmet microphone.

The SCAT rolls down the ramp and onto the tarmac. Betty accelerates through the open gate and into the city streets. Behind you, you notice the cargo ramp lifting up and the ship’s security systems activate.

Driving through the city streets you soon realise that it is going to be harder to find something than you had anticipated. There are no signs of recent movement. Everything is covered in layers of sand and it seems that not even the cockroaches survived the planet’s ordeal.

Up ahead you notice movement. You catch a brief glimpse of an object disappearing around a corner. Was it a plastic bag being blow by the wind, or maybe your imagination?

“Look at this boss”, Betty says stopping in the middle of the street, pointing to a manhole cover.

“What are we looking at”, you ask not understanding why Betty is so excited.

“A couple of times I’ve note a bright glint on the manhole covers as we drove by”, he explains.

“And”, you ask not following.

“Well, a metal surface usually looses it’s metallic lustre after a while, but as you can see, these are newly made scratches.”

Looking closer you realize Betty is correct. The manhole cover has been opened and closed recently, and by the look of it numerous times.

“Shall we get down there and have a look around “, Betty asks.

Still perplexed by what you saw up ahead, you have to decide...
1321.title: Go to the City

choices: Get the hell out of here
13211.content:
“Let’s check out the manholes”, you say. “It probably used to be their sewer system.”
Betty switches the SCAT off and dismounts. You join him and both of you stand looking at the manhole cover, Jackhammers in hand.

“Shall we drop in an HE-grenade for good luck”, Betty asks.

“Yeah, and blow away the people we want to bargain with”, you say.

“What if it’s filled with mutants”, he wonders out loud.

“What if it’s not”, you reply.

“Fine, we’ll just throw down a flare then”, Betty shrugs.

You lift the cast iron manhole cover that is light as a feather due to your mechanised armour. Betty pops a flare and throws it down the hole. It drops approximately four meters before hitting the dry floor. You see step irons line the one side of the manhole.

“After you, Cappy”, Betty says with a smirk.

You adjust the shoulder strap of your Jackhammer so that it hangs from your back, and switch the spread light on your helmet on. Then you carefully start climbing down the manhole. Halfway down, the step irons are replaced by a cat ladder, which hangs down the two meter wide pipe-tunnel.

In the flickering light of the flare, you can see the tunnel extending in both directions. Turning your spread light to its maximum setting, it shines down the tunnel, but fails to penetrate the darkness.

From above, Betty descends and steps off next to you. “This place gives me a creepy feeling, man”, he says holding his Jackhammer at the ready.

“Look there”, you say pointing to the ground. In the light of you headlamp, you can clearly see foot prints in the dust.

“Those look like military issue boot-prints”, you say. “And they’re fresh.”

A loud clang makes you and Betty look up to see the sunlight that was shining in through the manhole opening disappears.

“What the f…”, you hear Betty whisper.

“Let’s get out of here”, you say taking the lead up the cat ladder. Reaching the manhole cover, you press up against it with your right hand while holding on to a step iron with your left. You can feel the step irons strain against the weight. With a loud bang, the step irons break free from the concrete they are imbedded in and you fall down to land on your back at Betty’s feet. A second later the cat ladder lands on top of you.

“There’s something damn heavy on top of that cover”, you say getting up. “And with the cat ladder torn from the wall, there’s no way we’re getting back up there.”

“What if we just blow a hole through whatever is up there from below”, Betty proposes. “The Jackhammer will rip through that cover like a knife through butter.”

“Yeah, but how do we get up there…even if we do get it open”, you ask. “Let’s just follow the boot prints… that’s exactly why we are here…to find some humans and get the chip.”

Betty nods in agreement. “Let’s go.”

As the two of you walk away, the flare starts sputtering and dies down. It feels as if the darkness that increases around you, is tangible. You walk down the tunnel into the blackness.

“Let’s turn off our lights and switch to night vision”, you propose. “Try and fly below the radar, you know.”

With that you both switch off your lights and turn on your night vision. The inside of your helmets immediately turn light green as the visor displays an amplified image. In front of you, you can see the tunnel extending into the distance. A red dot on your visor indicates where your Jackhammer is pointing. And so you walk.

Five minutes later, you stop. In the side of the tunnel wall, someone has broken through. It is clear the tunnel branching off through the hole was not constructed by the original builders of the underground system. Looking down, you can see the boot prints leading into the unofficial branch.

“So what…” Betty starts saying before you shush him.

“Listen”, you say.

From within the new tunnel, you can hear a faint sound. You listen.

“It sounds like growling and moaning…there’s no way that that is human”, Betty says.

“So how do you explain the boot prints”, you ask Betty. “It leads straight down the tunnel.”

“I say we find the closest manhole and get the hell out of here”, Betty counters. “It’ll be dark in half an hour anyway.”
13211.title: Let's open the manhole and have a look

132111.content:
“No”, you say. “We follow the trail.”

“Man, I knew I shouldn’t have signed up for this”, Betty snarls adjusting the setting on his Jackhammer to ‘Full Power’.

With that, you step into the earthen tunnel. Slowly and quietly you edge your way forward. In spite of the temperature control of the combat armour, small droplets of sweat pearl on your forehead. The growling and moaning noises get closer.

Up ahead you notice the tunnel curling around a corner. From behind the corner and dim glow of yellow light falls into the tunnel.

“Ok”, you whisper to Betty. “Look sharp…we make this work or we die on this planet.”

Still you edge closer, until you’re about two feet from the turn. Leaning closer, you poke your head around the corner. What you see sends a cold shiver up your back.

In front of you, in the dim light, are rows of cages dangling from the ceiling by chains. Inside the cages are humans in varying conditions. Some look weak and skinny, while others are fit and muscular. Your eyes drift down when you see something even more shocking.

On the ground, the cages are being patrolled by something. It looks humanoid in that it has two legs and two arms, but its skin is green and glistening. It’s wearing army-style camouflage pants and combat boots and carries what looks like an assault rifle. It has obscure dimensions - almost apelike and its face reminds you of a typical fairy-tale troll. A quick scan reveals that the “troll” is alone and that there is one metallic door in the back of the room. The humans are the ones moaning, and every now and again, the “troll” growls at them and bangs on their cages.

Sitting back, you relay the details to Betty.

“What do we do now”, he asks.

“I’ll bet my danger pay that that is a mutant and that the humans and mutants don’t see eye to eye. I think we can take him, rescue the humans and if we’re lucky get a synchropter-chip as reward.”

“Wow”, Betty says smiling. “What a rich imagination you have Cappy. I say we save our skins and get the hell out of here.”

What do you do next?
132111.title: Follow the trail

1321111.content:
“You’re right. Let’s bail”, you say, deciding it’s too dangerous.

As you get up to leave, you activate your night vision for the return trip. Ahead of you, you see movement in the darkness.

“Three mutants dead ahead”, you whisper and open fire.

The blue bolt from the Jackhammer shoots through the tunnel and connects with the leg of the mutant in front. Shooting his leg out from under him he falls face first to the ground. Betty fires his gun and takes down the second mutant.

With a deafening growl, the third mutant comes running toward you. You both open fire and fell him as well. With smoke drifting up from your Jackhammers, you scan the scene.

“Let’s move out”, you say and start to run. From around the corner to your front another mutant appears, followed by another and another. When they see you, they become enraged and attack. Firing as fast as you can, you try to keep them at bay.

Then you realise that there are also mutants coming from your rear. Standing back to back with Betty, you both fire frantically, trying to keep your head above water.

More and more mutants come pouring around the corners. In a cold panic, you realise the inevitable. They are too many.

Pouring over you in a green wave, your adventure ends in the sewers of Gefahr, with the sound of your bones cracking as you sink away into oblivion.
The End
1321111.title: Get the hell out

1321112.content:
“No”, you say firmly. “We help the humans.”

Seeing that there is no arguing with you, Betty checks his gun again. “Right…let’s do it.”

“Ok, we head out together. You pop the mutant while I go for the door. We don’t want that door opening and more of the pouring out. Once I have secured the door, we start opening the cages. When we leave you take the front, I’ll bring up the rear. The first manhole you find, we get out to the streets...got it?” you ask looking at Betty.

“Piece ‘f cake”, he says seemingly unbothered.

As one the two of you step out into the door. The mutant sees you, but before he can do anything a blue bolt from Betty’s gun tears through his chest. You sprint toward the door in the back. Reaching it, you see it starting to swing open. You slam into the door, trying to force it shut. You encounter fierce resistance from the other side.

Straining against the door, you know it is your mechanical muscle against the mutant’s muscle riddled bodies. For a few seconds you think you’re going to lose the battle, when you finally manage to force the door shut and secure the lock. The door rattles heavily.

“Let’s go”, you scream at Betty seeing that he has the key that the mutant was carrying.

Within seconds you have the people out of the cages.

“Go, go, go”, you say to Betty.

“Wait”, a young man to your left says. “I know a shortcut.”

“Show us”, you reply.

Leading the group out, you wait for the last person to leave before placing a high explosive grenade next to the door and activating its proximity detonator.

You follow the group down the dark tunnel. Seconds later you are knocked to the floor followed by a thunderous bang. They’re in the tunnel, you think.

“How are we doin’ up there”, you ask Betty over your microphone.

“The dude says we’re almost there”, he replies and you keep following the staggered trail formation of running people.

From behind you hear growls and howls. Unclipping another grenade, again you activate the proximity detonator and drop it by your side, still running.

This time you hear no bang. Can the mutants be that clever, you wonder. Then you spot one thirty yards behind you...no make that three, four... “Aah, shit”, you whisper to yourself.

Crouching to one knee, you set your Jackhammer to full automatic, and release a burst of three rounds. They cut the two front mutants down. After firing another burst, you get up and run. Then you stop and fire again. More mutants come pouring out. They’re catching up. You rate of fire is not keeping up with the number of mutants that are pouring towards you. Twenty yards.

“How we doin’?” you ask sounding deceivingly calm.

“Almost there”, you hear again.

Firing again, you decide you will have to hang back and keep the mutants from killing the whole group. If you have to sacrifice yourself then so be it...Betty can finish the mission.

“We got it”, you hear him say over your earpiece.

Quickly the people climb up a ladder and into the daylight above.

You unclip your last grenade, this time activating the time delay detonator before flinging the grenade into the approaching horde. Then you climb up the ladder. As you fall over the side onto the street, the explosion from below shoots a geyser of green goo and mutant body parts out the opening.

The young man that lead the way replaced the manhole cover. “Follow me”, he says running away.
1321112.title: Free the humans

133.content:
“No”, you say adamantly. “We fight with them.”

Swearing under his breath, Betty powers up the ship’s shields and cannons.

“Wake up you assholes – we’ve got incoming”, he growls at the escort as he turns the ship in a wide arc to meet the approaching Wasps.

You notice the escort turning and firing up their afterburners to rush to the enemy, who are still outside visual range.

An alarm sounds, accompanied by flashing red lights on the control panel.

“Long range missiles inbound”, the female voice of the computer calmly announces. On the screen you see the three red triangles indicating the Wasps and four yellow lines speeding straight at you.

“See that”, Betty asks with venom in his voice. “Those are Viper missiles, and our countermeasures don’t fool them. The escort is as good as lost.”

With the escorts speeding ahead of you, you see the first missile approach the front ship. It launches a spectrum of electronic countermeasures and decoys. The missile flies straight and the explosion consumes the entire ship.

“Hold on”, Betty says as he pulls the Juggernaut in a tight turn whilst yanking down on a red leaver. She ship shakes violently accompanied by a loud metalling screech. Then he punches the controls and the ship shuts down completely. Finally he turns off the lights. From the side you can see the missile speeding closer.

“What have you done?” you ask feeling cold sweat pearl on your forehead.
“I dumped everything in the cargo hold…all the mining equipment, everything. It might fool the missiles since they were carefully calibrated to distinguish our countermeasures and disregard them. The mining equipment might ...”

Before Betty can finish, you slam back into your seat as the force of the explosion knocks the ship forward. Straining against your seat belt, the ship tumbles bow over stern, rolling away into empty space.

“Shiiiit”, you scream while holding on. Small electronic fires erupt and a hydraulic line breaks spraying oil across the cockpit.

“Hang on”, Betty screams. “With the destroyed mining equipment, the Wasps might mistake the debris for our ship. But we can’t do anything to let them know were still alive. We’re gonna have to ride this out – faking a portion of debris spinning into space.”

In the vacuum of space, Pathfinder Seven Zero spins away uncontrollably, while you extinguish the fires from the strapped-in safety of your chair. Fifteen minutes later, you can swear you’ve developed a hernia. “I think we’re clear”, Betty says powering the ship up. He engages the stabilizers. On the wings you can see them puffing in protest, slowing the uncontrollable spin until eventually the ship stops completely.

Looking at Betty, his eyes are blood red from the blood rushing to his head from the spinning.

“Looks like you’ve been drinking “, he says looking at you.

“Speak for yourself”, you reply. “Now what”, you ask.

“Well, now we need to get mining equipment again and for that we have two options I know about: the first is Hector-Prime...lovely little planet. I have some friends there, but the last time I was there an asshole-bounty hunter called Griffin was looking for me. We had a bit of a falling out and I severed his hand before escaping the planet…he might still be there and he is probably still pissed.

Second is Procol-Kilia. It’s a sub-surface hell-hole. We can only land when the port is on the dark side, cause the day-light side is pretty much a lava-firestorm due to the heat from the closest star. The subsurface facility is controlled by the Guhl, but we should be able to fly under the radar as long as we can maintain the miner faÃ§ade.
133.title: Turn and fight with the escort

14.content:
“Very good Captain. Your ship awaits in port 34-Delta. Good luck.”

As you enter port 34 Delta, you are welcomed by a man in his fifties wearing a grey trench coat.

“Pleased to meet you Captain. I am Lord Freeman – at your service.”

Freeman shakes your hand with a firm grip and looks you straight in the eyes. The combination of his greying hair, his green-grey eyes and his grey trench coat almost gives him a benign quality. However, knowing the way that trade masters operate, you decide that he will have to earn your trust the hard way.

Turning your attention to the Freelancer, you are impressed. The ship is the newest range of the Freelancer series, so called due to its versatility. Weapons-, cargo- and electronic utility pod-bays are interchangeable and with a large cargo hold it can carry anything from cargo to weapons or soldiers. A common favourite of space rangers and bounty hunters, the Freelancer series had proven its track record in action.

“Ah, here they are”, you hear Freeman say behind you. Turning around you see three men enter the port. As the first one reaches you he extends his hand and introduces himself, “Captain Gunn, I am Commandant Reginald Reddling. I will be your navigator on this mission.”

“Welcome Commandant,” you reply easily. “I see your record says you graduated from the Academy under Admiral Miraz.”

“Yes…uh…sir,” Reddling replies, seemingly not sure how to address you since he technically outranks you.

“You can just address me as Captain, Commandant. I know it’s unorthodox to have a mission commander that does not outrank you, but trust me there is a good reason I find myself in this position.”

Slightly intimidated by the calibre of your crew, you wish you hadn’t said that, realizing that it sounded as if you were trying to convince someone.

Moving on, you encounter the next person in line.

“Master Chief Sam McGuire sir,” the engineer says. His bulky frame and log-like arms do not fit his job description. The engineers you are used to are more of the geeks-in-glasses type. With his five-o’clock-shadow and jet-black hair, it looks like McGuire just strolled out of a pub. A slight belch escapes McGuire’s mouth. Smelling alcohol on his breath, you realise McGuire did just step out of the ship’s pub.

“No worries sir. There’s also a good reason I find myself in this position…” McGuire responds sensing your doubt in him. “I find,” he starts elaborating, “that a quick drink before a mission relaxes me and…”

“That’s fine, Chief,” you reply cutting him off. “I’m sure the fleet commanders had good reason assigning you to this mission.”

With some concern, you step past him to the last person in line – the language expert. Not getting a good look when the three crew members came in, you are surprised to see it’s a woman.

With dark-brown hair and brown eyes, you are taken aback by her good looks and hesitate for a moment.

“Lieutenant-Commander Michelle Shields, Captain,” she says, taking the opportunity.
Oh great, you think to yourself, another person that outranks me.

“Let’s move out people,” you say, not wanting to extend your torture any further. “We’re on a tight schedule.”

Three minutes later you find yourself strapped into the pilot’s seat. With expert fingers you punch the controls in front of you, making the console blink to life. Shortly after that, the ship’s engines whine alive.

“Pathfinder seven-zero, you are clear for takeoff,” the voice of the space traffic controller-robot announces over your earpiece. Powering the engines up, you find yourself sliding though the open hatch of the America.

“Commandant Reddling,” you say over the microphone strapped to your throat, “what is the closest destination to a trade centre so that we can get rid of the extra Pylene and stock up for the mining operation?”

“That would be the Kepler sir. It is actually a mining station, but there are small numbers of traders that would buy our Pylene. They should also have the appropriate mining tools. There are however Miras-Guhl on Kepler sir, and we would have to go in quietly,” Reddling says confidently.

“Our second option is a planet called Rokkla. It’s quite a bit further away and we would have to use 30% of our Pylene stock to get there. Prices there are also quite low for Pylene, but there are no Miras-Guhl on Rokkla.”

Looking at Freeman, he nods in agreement, confirming what Reddling had just said.

“I believe we should consider a third option, Captain,” Freeman says.

“There is a decommissioned penal-facility on a small planet nearby called La Mort. It doesn’t display on our star maps, because it’s not supposed to exist anymore. However smugglers use it as a relay station. They pay top dollar for Pylene, and have an impressive inventory of weapons and equipment.”

“If they don’t kill us first,” Lieutenant-Commander Shields chips in.

Looking back at Freeman, he rubs his chin. “That is a possibility,” he responds, “but only if they learn we’re with the law, as it were. It can also be our fastest ticket to completing our mission.”

With all the crew looking at you, you have to decide:
14.title: Freelancer 2200 multi-purpose trade ship

choices: Activate shields, arm weapons, attack speed, tight left turn.
Activate shields and enter planet’s atmosphere immediately.
Let's not follow typical military strategy...let's rather do the following
141.content:
“Kepler it is,” you say looking at navigator Reddling. He starts programming the navigation systems.

“We’ll go in as traders. The fake identification chips on the ship should fool the Guhl into believing that. We get what we need and we get out of there.” With that you grab the controls of the ship, engage the warp drive and shoot away into space.

“Approaching planet Kepler,” the computer announces.

Your ship disengages the warp drive and slides into a stationary orbit above Kepler. The planet glows red and reminds you of one of the planets named Mars in the Old Earth galaxy.

“Ok”, you start, “let’s...”

“Warning, warning”, the computer cuts you off. “Hostile ship approaching from the rear. Targeting system of approaching ship has locked on to our signal.”

You realize that you have to act quickly. What instructions do you issue?
141.title: Kepler

1412.content:
You quickly activate the shields as you are fired on, and push forward on your controls entering the planets atmosphere, leaving behind the attacker. Your ship spirals out of control as a high-energy round hits the bow.

“Lucky shot”, you whisper as you fight to regain control of the ship.

You end up crash landing on the planet as the attacker left little damage, but enough to send the ship out of control.

"Busted aileron", you say looking at damage report on the ship's display.

Strapping your gauss pistol on, you get out of the ship unharmed and look around to see your environment. You notice the planet looks deserted from where you are but notice lights in the far distance.
1412.title: Activate shields and enter planet’s atmos...

choices: The buggy fails to start up
14121.content:
“Right,” you say, trying to take control, “Commandant Reddling, any ideas as to whereabouts on the planet we have landed?”
“Sorry, Captain but all my equipment became disabled when he were hit.”
“Okay, Master Chief McGuire?”
“Captain.” You turn to see your engineer already getting stuck into his suddenly heavier workload.
“Good. You remain here with Commandant Reddling and see what you can do to fix her up. Commandant, you’re in charge until I return. Lord Freeman, I believe that your expertise in bartering will come in useful here so I want you to accompany me.”
“Very good Captain, I’ll start to load the buggy with some Pylene.”
“Good. McGuire, have you had a once over? Is there anything you need?”
“A couple of aileron spades for the left wing but other than that I don’t think there is much more damage that a hammer won’t fix.”
“Captain? Your orders for me, Captain?” Lieutenant Commander Shields enquired.
“Lieutenant, you stay here, under the command of Reddling and...”
“Stay here? Begging your pardon, Captain but wouldn’t it be better for me to join you and Lord Freeman...”
“No, no, we’ll be travelling blind and it’s far too...”
“Dangerous? You don’t think I can hack it?”
“No, it’s not that, it’s just that...”
“I’m coming! And you can apologise later.” She turns away to go and help pack the buggy leaving you speechless. Reddling replaces her by your side.
“Not being undermined are you, Captain?”
“No, no. Everything’s, uh, everything’s shiny. Everything is AOK. Think you can manage while I’m gone?”
“Will you?” Reddling jokes, “Anyway, here’s a small map of Kepler. This is the mining station, you’ll find everything you need there, the miner’s settlement is just next to it but watch out, here is a known Miras-Guhl settlement. It’s only small but the population is unknown.”
“Thanks. Let’s hope we don’t head straight for that then.”
“Well, I think we landed somewhere in this area, judging by the surroundings and the current alignment of the skies.”
“So if we take a course heading across here then we’ll be fine.”
“Hypothetically yes, but this map is very old, any new settlements or landmarks will be missing. But if I had to, I’d say heading for the light is your best bet. If we are where I think we are that should be the mining station.”
“Okay, thanks for the heads up.”

Heading back into the ship to check on the buggy you find it fully loaded for the experiment.
“Are you ready Captain?” Lieutenant Commander Shields asks.
“Yes. Hop in, let’s get this show on the road.”
14121.title: Head towards the light

141212.content:
Heading towards the fast approaching light of the village you start to see the formation of huts and begin to doubt the friendliness of the inhabitants. Unsure of whether to continue approaching, in fear that it was in fact a Miras Guhl settlement, you slow the buggy down to a stop. Looking at your crew, you report your worries that it may be unsafe to enter the colony ahead of them.

The buggy is a small craft that virtually makes no sound, due to the advanced hover technology used, convincing you that it could easily pass through the village undetected, had it been darker however in the current daylight sneaking through would prove more difficult.

Having noticed the sudden stopping of the buggy, Lieutenant Commander Shields, breaks into your thoughts,

“Captain? Has something gone wrong with the buggy?”

You express your concerns to the buggy's other passengers,

"No, I’m just worried about entering the settlement. We don’t know for sure that it is a safe, miner’s town. It could be a new Miras-Guhl town that isn’t shown on this map. Obviously the buggy would be able to pass through practically undetectable but for me to be confident of this, we will have to wait for it to get much darker."

Once they had taken in this information, Michelle suggested,

"Couldn't we pass ourselves off as Miras Guhl men? I know the basic dialect, just let me do all the talking!"

"That might work," Freeman considered, "however we may just be able to buy our way through, we have more than enough pylene and Miras Guhl men are known for their greediness, it will be easy to persuade them to exchange the pylene for safe passage to the mining town."

You remain unsure and pull out Reddling's chart. It indicates that to go around the village would take a good couple of hours, due to the long width of the settlement, which was going to use much more pylene than originally planned therefore leaving less to eventually bargain with at the mining station. Also, the crew back at the ship may start to worry as going round would almost double their journey time. he didn't want them risking their lives organising a search party for them, especially as the Freelancer 2000 was only equipped with the one buggy and so they would be setting off unprotected with no vehicle. It was however the safest route with no danger of meeting any enemy lines. Waiting for darkness to fall would take even longer, looking at the sky you reckon you still have at least four more hours of daylight, so sneaking through the village also added extra time onto the original journey time.

Alternatively you could go along with your crewmate's idea and head through the town and hope that either they are the miner's homes or that they are persuadable Miras Guhl. Although your crew seem keen to head straight through the town, you know from previous experience that Miras-Guhl warriors don’t tend to be negotiable and are more likely to kill you for the pylene than trade for it.

You decide to..........
141212.title: Risk It?

1412121.content:
“We have to risk it”, you say without doubt.
“Time is of the essence and the entire fleet...all of the OEA is depending on us. We push on.”
Looking at the faces around you, you see that your crew is in agreement.
“Prep your weapons and keep your eyes open. If the Guhl is here and something goes down it’s gonna happen fast and hard...and when the moment comes that you have to pull your trigger, I don’t want anybody hesitating”, you finish staring at the crew with no combat experience.
Smoothly the cruiser accelerates towards the settlement. You scan the colony through your binoculars. It seems desolate. A few open doors and windows are swept open and shut in the dry wind. You see mining tools and pieces of equipment standing around. Well at least it doesn’t look like its a Miras Guhl camp...but where are the miners?
“Binoculars to infrared”, you command you binoculars.
Your eyes see no heat signatures.
“Binoculars to normal; amplify”, you say.
You notice strange paint marks on the equipment and tools. Random splatters...of...you feel the hairs on your neck stand on end.
Not paint splutters...blood smears. All over the place. Even dry patches of blood on the ground.

You briefly consider turning back, but realise it’s too late for that now. You need to get to the other side, that’s why you decided to push on even if it did mean danger is at hand.
“An entire mining colony...gone” you whisper.
“Should we stop and investigate Captain, or proceed at full speed”, Freeman asks you.
1412121.title: Risk It?

choices: "I can't seem to reach the ship"
14121212.content:
“Better to push on, I want to return swiftly to the ship so that she can be repaired and back on mission as soon as. Take note though, we may need to report back to the Alliance.”

“Roger that, Captain.” Michelle acknowledges, whipping out her notebook and beginning to scribble furiously. You exchange a raised eyebrow with Lord Freeman as he regards, “What else did you bring with you?” When the comment receives an unimpressed response, you refocus the team on the task.

“Right, according to Commandant Reddling’s map, he was right. This hardly looks like the Miras-Guhl settlement, though the new decor suggests a visit, therefore if we continue a mile or two with a slight bend to the right from this angle,” you indicate a crude pathway between two of the larger huts, “we should be able to reach the mining station avoiding detection from the enemy camp.”

Your crew accept the plan and you steer the buggy through the empty town towards the direction of the mining station, trying to ignore the signs of casualty painted across the homes. Emerging from the town, the station can be seen on the horizon, with a clear way leading on. Bearing in mind the Miras-Guhl settlement that you wish to avoid you turn the vehicle to bear slightly right so that you can reach the mine without detection.

Upon entering the mining base, you breathe a sigh of relief for the Miras-Guhl settlement, as shown on the map, is relatively close to the mine and yet you managed to manoeuvre the buggy to enter without exposure.

Looking around, the emptiness of the town echoes over the mine, with clear signs showing that the previous users of the mine had ceased work long before now.
“Lord Freeman, it seems your skills in trade are no longer required, how’s your scavenging? You know we currently have nothing in the way of equipment for mining this new power source, what it is we will need for the expedition?”
“Well, all we know about the power comes from the information sent to us from the alternative power supply exploration team, before the source was discovered by Miras-Guhl. Examination of the new found material ceased, protection becoming the imperative action.”
“So, we still don’t know the exact manner of this new material?”
“Not really, no.”
“Lieutenant? Can you see if you can get Master Chief McGuire on the two-way intercom system.”
“Captain, the radio waves may be detected by the Miras-Guhl camp, they could easily be intercepted, we’re closer to them now than we are our own ship.”
“Yes, but we have no other alternative at this moment. I didn’t anticipate having to locate the equipment myself. This mining station is not listed abandoned.”
Michelle looks at you with slight disgust in your clear disregard for the small battlefield just crossed, “Something tells me, they were a little busy fighting for their lives to call in a closed until further notice.”
“Lieutenant, I’m not denying a tragedy has plainly occurred here, but it did so much later than this mining station closed, look around, this mine hasn’t been used in a hell of a long time. it’s practically become a junkyard. Try to get through to McGuire. Lord Freeman, I need you to check the station tower, see if you can find out why this mine was closed.”
“You think the closing has anything to do with the Miras-Guhl, Captain?”
“I don’t know. This place doesn’t look like it has been officially shut down, more like, abandoned.”

Looking around confirms this theory as the ground is littered with tools and the machinery rusted into positions unseen in disused mining stations.
“Captain?” Michelle regains your attention.
14121212.title: The Mining Station

142.content:
“We wanna fly under the radar, so we’re going for Rokkla”, you say confidently. “Commandant Reddling, please set the course.”

Within seconds the course is set and the ship smoothly transitions to warp speed. The stars and planets visible through the front portals blur out of view and then back again.

“Sir”, Reddling exclaims, “we’re tracking a scrambled distress signal to our portside. It reads as an OEA ship...but the strange thing...is that it seems that the signal has been transmitting for over a decade.”

“What does the signal say, Commandant”, you ask.

“Mayday, mayday”, you hear over the intercom as Reddling plays the message. “Emergency distress signal...ship identification: OEA explorer-class Intrepid 504, crew: fifteen, status: all crew dead, ship severely damaged, cargo: high priority cargo - classified, please assist.”

“Computer”, you say, “check the database for the ship ‘Intrepid 504’.

You wait in silence as the ship scans its database.

“Ship: Intrepid 504”, the female voice on the computer complies.
“Last mission recorded: October 2133.”
“Mission Commander: Colonel Marshall Brooke”
“Mission details: Classified”
“Mission status: Contact with the Intrepid was lost as it was returning from deep space. Priority cargo was never returned. All rescue missions were aborted. Cause of disappearance unknown. Recovery of cargo of utmost importance. Any OEA ship coming into contact with the Intrepid should report its position immediately and secure the cargo for retrieval.”

“What shall we do sir”, Reddling asks. “We’re five minutes away from Rokkla...and to be honest, we’re already on a priority mission.”

“I’ve heard of this”, Lieutenant Commander Shields chips in. “I did a brief stint in Intelligence and there the story was somewhat of a legend. It was referred to as the Intrepid mystery.” Looking around, Shields saw that she had everybody’s attention and continued.

“Rumour has it that the Intrepid was rigged with a prototype inter-dimensional transporter. A device that could apparently enable the ship to explore other dimensions. However the theory behind it was somewhat questionable. For the ship to make inter dimensional jumps, it required obscene amounts of energy. Energy that could be tapped from high-energy fields in supernovas. Brooke was ordered to take the ship out to a supernova known as Thor’s pillars. It was on the fringes of charted space back then. Anyway, apparently they made the journey safely there and ‘jumped’ the super nova as it was called. However, as far as anybody could tell, they never made the return journey. The project for the pursuit of inter dimensional travel called ‘Tartarus’ was stopped after the failed mission. Nobody knows what dimension they were heading for or what the details of their mission were. It was also mentioned that they have a high priority cargo, but whether this refereed to the prototype device that could enable inter dimensional travel, or if it referred to something they picked up on the other side, was never clear...One thing has always been clear though, the OEA would love to get their hands on the lost Intrepid 504.”

“What do we do, Captain”, Reddling asks after a moment of silence.
142.title: Rokkla

1422.content:
“If it’s so important to the OEA, we have to go after it”, you say. “Commandant, head for the Intrepid.”

Five minutes later you see the Intrepid appear in front of you. It is clearly an older ship, but you can tell it is rigged for a special mission. It seems completely dead.

“Ok, let’s gear up and have a look”, you say. “ Reddling and Freeman stays here. Shields and McGuire, you come with me.”

“What on earth would you want a communications expert on an abandoned ship for”, Shields asks.

“I need an extra pair of eyes and someone that can think on their feet”, you reply. “Anyway, we need the navigator and trade master if someone has to finish the mission.”

With that, the three of you proceed to the decompression hangar. Outfitting yourselves in self-propelled space suits, you each grab a plasma rifle.

“You never can be too sure”, you say charging the rifle. “Let’s head out.”

After closing your helmet visor, the compartment decompresses and the hatch opens. In front of you, you see the Intrepid.

“Deactivate ship’s gravity generator”, you say and as you become weightless, you activate the suit’s propulsion system. You slowly accelerate through the open hatch, followed by your engineer and communications expert.

Drifting closer to the Intrepid, you see there are two possible entry points; the main entry hatch towards the front and a lesser known service hatch near the back.

Where will you enter?
1422.title: Check out the Intrepid 504

14222.content:
Reaching he servce hatch, you insert your remote communications port into the universal port.

"Reddling" you say, "Transmit an opening code."

Within seconds the hatch opens and you slide in. Inside you see a passage going left and one going right.
14222.title: The service hatch.

143.content:
“We head for La Mort,” you say easily.”The ninth star fleet will soon fall and that will leave a gaping hole in the OEA defences. If we don’t act quickly, all might be lost. Besides, our ship was fitted with a rewired id-chip, so scanners shouldn’t be able to detect our true identity…for all they know, we’re simple privateers.”

“Set a course for La Mort, Commandant,” you say to Reddling. “Strap in everyone,” you say as you prepare the warp drives.

“Coordinates set, Captain,” Reddling replies.

“Engaging warp-drive,” you say activating the engines.

With a shudder the Freelance makes the transition to warp speed.

***

“Approaching La Mort,” the onboard computer announces.

“Warp drive, deactivation sequence started.”

The ship shudders again and as it decelerates to cruising speed, La Mort flashes into view. Peering from the bridge window, you see a dark – almost black – planet.

The computer commences with a briefing of the planet’s statistics.

“Planet name: La Mort.
Atmosphere composition: 81.01% nitrogen, 20.85% oxygen, 0.93% argon, 0.038% carbon dioxide, remainder – trace elements. Atmosphere, breathable.
Temperature: -5 to 45 degrees Celsius.
Climate: no rainfall.
Geology: 99,9% Obsidian formations consisting of Silicon Dioxide, remainder – trace elements.
Life: non detectable.
Structures: non detectable.”

“The smugglers pay lots of money to keep it that way,” Freemen says rubbing his chin.

“So what now,” you ask looking at Freemen. “Where is the penal facility?”
“Now we knock,” Freemen says.

“Commandant Reddling, do you know old Morse code,” Freemen asks.

“I do,” Shields replies sitting up in her chair. “What…I’m a language expert – you’d be surprised at what I know,” she says sensing the whole crew is looking at her with surprise.

“Lieutenant-Commander Shields please proceed by transmitting the letters I dictate,” Freemen says.

Looking at McQuire, you see he is already connecting Shield’s console to the communications transmitter.

“ R,” Freemen starts spelling the word and Shields start tapping the controller in front of her.
“O…B…E…R…T…O…break… C…O…F…R…E…S…I…”

Shields finishes tapping the Morse code and looks up at Freemen. “Now what,” she asks.

“That’s it,” Freemen says looking at you. “Now we wait…the name Roberto Cofresi is the name I’ve been given by the Free Traders Guild or FREETRAG as they are commonly called, when I became a member. Their computer will check my status and if I’m welcome they’ll let us in.”

“What if you did something to piss them off,” you ask expectantly.

“They will shoot our ship from the sky without asking questions,” Freemen answers smoothly.

“FREETRAG…aren’t they an underground terrorist organisation?” McGuire asks.

“Terrorist is a word so easily used these days,” Freemen replies. “If a group employs the full benefits of a free market system these days, they get labelled as a ‘terrorist’ organisation. So they bend trade regulations now and again…is that really such a crime?”

“What about the battle cruiser they sold to the Guhl,” Shields asks.

“What about it,” Freemen asks, turning around to look at her. “Is it not a willing buyer willing seller arrangement? If the OEA wanted it so bad, they should have bought it.”

“Can we leave the debate for later please,” you demand, not wanting a fight to break out at this stage of the mission.

“Captain, a missile turret has surfaced on the planet – nuclear tipped Super Novas. One of those babies will vaporize us for sure…what do I do?” Reddling asks.
143.title: La Mort

1431.content:
"Open missile bays one and two, lock on target, shields up," you command.

"Missile bay one open, missile bay two open, missile turret locked on, shields up," the computer responds.

"Fire," you say and watch as the two missiles streak across the open sky towards the planet's surface. As the missiles enter the atmosphere they burst into flames, but you know they have been designed to survive atmosphere entry and will arrive at their target in tact.

The two smoke trails disappear in a distance as they reach into the planet’s atmosphere.

“Switching to missile-cams,” McGuire says. On the central control screen, two pictures appear. The one to the left is the front missile, and the one to the right the trailing one. Approaching the surface, a heptagon shape is visible on the planet’s surface. It is the missile battery.

“Goodbye,” you say with a smug smile playing over your lips.

Then you spot a flame shooting from the battery. Seconds later your missiles slam into their target and the screen goes blank.

“What was that flame,” McGuire asks.

“You saw it too,” Shields adds.

“Look at that,” Reddling says pointing to the surface of the planet. A third trail of smoke is visible, but this one is reaching up from the black planet.

“Missile inbound,” the computer announces.

“Launch countermeasures, activate sentry gun,” you blurt out in a panic.
“Counter measure pods empty, no sentry gun detected,” the computer responds evenly.

Your eyes widen in horror. “Oh shit.”
1431.title: Open fire and destroy the turret.

1432.content:
“Hold fire”, you command staring at the turret.
Suspended in silence everyone stares at the turret on the screen. A droplet of sweat pearls on your forehead.
“They’re going to blow us out of the fucking sky”, McGuire whispers.
Then the speaker crackles to life.
“Freelancer, declare your intentions.”
Without looking at you Freeman punches the transmit button.
“Our intention is to trade. This is Lord Freeman; member of FREETRAG. Please upload a docking sequence.”
His request is met by silence. Then the instrument cluster on the navigation panel starts flickering as a docking sequence is uploaded and the engines whine to life.
Looking at Freeman you notice a smile play across his face.
“Let’s not open the champagne just yet”, you caution him.
The Freelancer streaks across the sky and shakes as it enters the planet’s atmosphere.
“Docking sequence initiated”, the computer declares.
The Freelancer descends into a canyon and in a distant rock face you see heavy blast doors slide open revealing a landing platform. The Freelancer touches down and the blast doors close behind you.
Hoping this was not a mistake you unbuckle yourself. You walk down the Freelancer’s ramp followed by your crew. A reception party of three approaches you. Leading the group is a tall lean man dressed in black flanked by two armed guards. His dark hair and hooked nose gives him the appearance of a vulture. His dark brown eyes dart over the crew, until he spots Freeman.
“Well, well, well” he says with a cool smile. “Look who the solar winds blew in the front door.”
“Suvius”, Freeman says nodding to the FREETRAG commander.
“I never thought I would see you again” Suvius continues without looking at the rest of the crew. “You must appreciate that your reputation here is not what it once was. There are even those that would want to see you dead after what happened during your last visit.”
“Water under the bridge”, Freeman responds nonchalant. “I’m here to do business – and as the saying in FREETRAG goes, profit trumps all. Now we have a substantial amount of pylene on this ship and are willing to trade at a very reasonable rate. ”
“I’m always keen for a profit”, Suvius replies. “However, I do not want a war to break out in this profitable facility of ours. That said, I will allow you to send one representative to trade on your behalf. You and the rest of your crew will remain on board your ship until you are ready to leave.”
“I’m the only FREETRAG member in this party and as you know only FREETRAG members can trade here”, Freeman objects.
“True enough old friend” Suvius replies with a sinister glimmer in his eyes. “However, I will ensure your man gets into the trade hall, but then he’s on his own…or would you rather leave?”
1432.title: Wait and see what happens.

info.brief_description: You are Captain Jack Gunn of the 9th star fleet.The future of humanity rests in your hands
info.description:
It is 2144 and war rages in the universe. One hundred years earlier, mankind realized that earth would sustain them no longer. Humanity pulled together and shortly after developing warp technology, launched three missions into space to find a new home. The first, called Mission One, failed and was never heard of again. The second and third both struck gold by finding inhabitable planets. The best planet was selected and mankind prepared to leave earth for a better future.

However, tragedy struck when a power hungry General named Mirashid Guhlamnar turned against his own. General Guhlamnar decided to leave Earth with his pick of subordinates while sabotaging the remainder of the earth fleet, stranding them on a dying planet while claiming the new world for himself.

A decade later, the people of Earth managed to rebuild their fleet and left Earth as it faded and died. By then, General Guhlamnar had built an empire on the new world, based on greed, deceit and manipulation. His empire is called Miras-Guhl.

The people from earth found the second planet and formed the Old Earth Alliance. Shortly after that, the Miras-Guhl started attacking, relentless to rule and dominate the universe.

Since then, contact had been made with numerous alien civilisations, some peaceful, some more aggressive, but all avoiding the war-mongering humans. Is it because they are peaceful, or because they want to see who the victor is?

Just remember to check your Point of View, tense, spelling and grammar.
